title: chavez socialist experiment venezuela opinion
story: GDP growth will stall. Taxes will rise. We’ll even run out of Mars bars.But across the Atlantic, something has been ­happening that should give us all some perspective.Over the past decade, Venezuela has plunged into the abyss — but there’s been no civil war, no earthquakes or hurricanes.Just a brutal, corrupt government that has turned what was once Latin America’s richest country into a hellhole.Starvation rations plunged millions into hunger and ­malnutrition, with some resorting to eating dogs, cats, even zoo animals.People got into kne fights over the right to scavenge from a dumpster.Its economy is more than three times smaller than in . Inflation climbed into the thousands, then millions of per cent.The result has been a refugee crisis on the scale of the Syria conflict.No wonder tens of ­thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Caracas this week, declaring national assembly head Juan Guaido the legitimate president.All this is awful for the poor bloody Venezuelans.But what does it have to do with Britain The answer is that Venezuela wasn’t just a ­disaster. It was an experiment — cheered on by Jeremy Corbyn and his cronies.In , Hugo Chavez took over Venezuela.He ruled until his death in , when he was succeeded by his hand-picked protege Nicolas Maduro.Chavez modelled himself on Latin American ­revolutionaries like Fidel Castro and Simon Boli. He nationalised much of the oil industry — which dominates the ­Venezuelan economy — and imposed punitive taxes on foreign firms.He introduced price controls and later currency controls. He declared “economic war” on the “stateless ­bourgeoisie” and seized the goods of private companies he denounced as saboteurs.For Corbyn, the Chavez regime was an inspiration — a chance to see true socialism brought to le.Venezuela, Corbyn has said, “showed us that there is a dferent, and a better, way of doing things. It’s called socialism”.It wasn’t just Corbyn. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott and Corbyn’s media chief Seumas Milne have all praised the ­Venezuelan revolution.That “better way of doing things” has ruined tens of millions of lives but there has not been a hint of an apology from Corbyn.Normally, the fact that people are taking to the streets to free themselves of a vicious regime would be cheered to the rafters by the Left.Instead, there is the silence of those who find themselves ­hideously embarrassed.The few who are not ­staring at their shoes claim that Venezuela has been the ­victim of an American plot.That Maduro took, in McDonnell’s words, a “wrong turn” from Chavez’s true socialism.That it was all down to a falling oil price.Yes, Maduro took a wrong turn. But that turn was to follow the path laid out by Chavez.From the Soviet Union to Cuba to Venezuela, there is a long and shabby history of British left-wingers acclaiming a workers’ paradise — only to declare, once its ­failure is clear, that it wasn’t really socialist after all.Never mind the millions of lives ruined — let’s have another go!If he became Prime ­Minister, Corbyn might not succeed in turning Britain into Venezuela. But we’d be Caracas to let him try.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: karren brady influencers dont see kids friends cash
story: Weirdly, for those of us who grew up before the internet took off, that’s an actual job now.And who can blame people for ­saying: “‘Yes please” to money for doing not very much But there is something wrongInstagram users aren’t aware the ­celebrities they follow are being paid thousands of pounds — or even hundreds of thousands — to promote the products they are “recommending”.Advertisers know Instagram — which has a BILLION monthly users posting some million photos a day — is an incredibly powerful way of reaching young people.The more followers a star has, the greater their selling power.Kylie Jenner, who has million ­followers, is paid a whopping £, for every sponsored post.Under the  UK Consumer Protection From Unfair Trading regulations, ­celebrities paid to plug products are supposed to make that clear.But there are no simple guidelines.So while some celebs might say “sponsored” or “#ad” on a post, others are less open about it.That is why the Competition  ­Markets Authority conducted an ­investigation.And this week  British celebrities and “influencers” were found to have failed to follow consumer protection guidelines.They include singers Rita Ora and Ellie Goulding, models Alexa Chung and Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and video blogger Zoella.While all agreed to change their ways, none was taken to court where they might have faced fines or even jail time.“Influencers” might say the clue is in the name. They are paid to inspire you to buy stuff.Most insist they only endorse ­products they actually believe in — and we’d all hope they take their responsibility seriously.But it is easy to see how an offer of, say, £, to endorse something they “sort of” believe in might make it harder to hang on to those principles.Equally,guidelines aren’t strictly enforced, you can understand the temptation to convey the impression that you just happen to really like a particular laxative herbal tea, say, or a moisturiser that gives you a “glow”.It’s a grey area. And you might ask why it matters.But given recent news about the ­negative impact social media can have on the mental health of young people — and young women in particular — regulation of this brave new world affects us all.I need only point to another big story this week.Schoolgirl Molly Russell was  when she took her own le after showing “no obvious signs” of severe mental health issues.Her family later found she had been viewing material on social media linked to anxiety, depression, self-harm and suicide.Her father even went as far as accusing Instagram of “helping to kill her”.Social media makes it so easy to tap into someone’s daily le, their home-decor proclivities and their innermost thoughts.The intimate nature of Instagram lets you feel like these influencers are your friends, and the products they rave about their personal ­recommendations, not the outcome of a business deal.This is a real problem. But the mistake is much harder to makeadverts are clearly labelled as such.Part of the problem is how obsessed with celebrities our young people have become.When I was growing up, my main influenceswere my parents and my friends.Now, young people are influenced by people they will never meet.Some of these people, dare I say it, are talentless nobodies.You might argue you would have to be naive not to realise they are selling you something.Perhaps young people are not as cynical as the likes of me.And that is why regulation is key.IT’S hard to sympathise with Fungi, a “star” of hit telly documentary Benefits Street, who says universal credit is “the worst thing in the world”.Tracked down by this paper, James Clarkeclaimed his monthly payments had been more than halved and the all-in-one benefit was causing “hell” for him and others like him . . . because their booze budget has been cut.Fungi was claiming £ a month to spend on food and sundries. But this was slashed to £ – which doesn’t cover the £ a month he and his partner spend on strong cider.His rent, meanwhile, is paid in full via a separate taxpayer-funded handout.Fungi also says his drinking habit means he can’t work. Sorry, what Here’s another way of looking at it. People who work for eight hours a day don’t have the time to down three litres of cider a day.If Mr Clarke got a job, he might recover some of his self-esteem – and probably save his le in the process.Just to be clear – I BELIEVE in the benefits system.But it was invented to help people get back on their feet, to help those who can’t help themselves because of illness or disability.It should be a short-term measure, not a lestyle choice.In the meantime, the rest of us go to work to pay for this man’s rent and booze.All because he can’t be bothered to sort himself out.No wonder people get angry.In fact, I suspect most readers will have steam coming out of their ears.This man must start taking responsibility for himself.I SUPPOSE it was worth a shot for Diane Abbott to complain that Fiona Bruce was “badly briefed” and that her treatment as a list on Question Time was racist.But she can’t blame Fiona for her own incompetence in answering questions – and not just on Question Time.There are so many car-crash interviews to choose from . . . although the one in which Diane suggested police officers could be paid £ a year springs to mind.WHAT a nasty piece of work Dancing On Ice judge Jason Gardiner seems.We expect the judges to give feedback.And we know it won’t all be good.But his comment to Gemma Collins last week – “We are not going to see big lts from you” – came across as body-shaming.Because his real point is that she is overweight, right It’s shocking, really. I’m surprised ITV allowed it.THE secret behind Elle Macpherson’s phenomenal bod has been revealed.In an interview, she said it all comes down to . . . late breakfasts.Hmmm. No matter when we eat breakfast, most of us will never come close to looking how she does at .Actually, forget breakfast times. What struck me is her diet seems to contain just FIVE ingredients . . . one of which is nut cheese.And the only liquid is water.Elle looks great.But by God, she must be miserable.THE Premier League’s popularity continues to soar, as a study into attendances across Europe proves.And I was immensely proud to see West Ham ranked seventh by attendance in all of Europe last year.We are up there with the Continent’s elite, in a table headed by Barcelona.And that will only get better now the capacity of the London Stadium is up to , – adding to the incredible support we get from what I believe are the league’s best fans.This week, accountancy firm EY published a report on the impact the Premier League has on our economy.It generates £.billion a year in tax for the Exchequer, supporting , jobs and contributing £.billion overall to the country’s GDP.Last season, Premier League players paid more than £billion in taxes.But never mind the money.It’s still the best league in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no delaying halting brexit john mann
story: Across the country people who voted dferent ways in the Brexit referendum are ­becoming bored and irritated by the silly games at Westminster.The truth is that a large majority of MPs are Remainers in their hearts and souls and are struggling to bring themselves to recognise the reality of the situation.It was us MPs who voted to give you, the people, the say on leaving or remaining in the European Union.And you voted, in higher numbers than you have ever bothered voting for any of us. Yet the same MPs who gave you a say are coming up with every excuse for why your views should not be listened to.Of course there are Remainer MPs whose constituencies voted heavily to remain.There are MPs with, I have to say it, courage, who have always argued strongly in a way that they have always known is dferent to their ­voters. These people are ­consistent and have my respect.But there are just as many who are in danger now of sitting on the fence until rigor mortis sets in, coming up with process rather than substance.They are simply hoping that others will do the dirty deed and respect the will of the people.It is also, for every Labour and Conservative MP, the manesto ­promise that we stood on at the last election. We voted for a referendum. We promised to respect the result.We got re-elected promising the same, yet Parliament continues to sit on the roundabout to nowhere.It is time to stop the shenanigans and work across the political ide to bring our country and our people together.At stake is our democracy. And in a democracy the winner prevails.Of course, in future years, people can argue that we have got it wrong and that people are entitled to change their mind. But for democracy to be true and real, we have to deliver the mandate we have been given and leave the EU on March .The referendum ided people and families, with lots of strong and dfering views. But in cherishing our democracy, we now need to come together to deliver a Brexit that respects the people’s vote and helps heal that ide.In le we have to compromise. We all have our own perfect Brexit, me included. And with ten of my colleagues we have forced through a big part of that, guaranteeing in law workers’ rights, health and safety and environmental standards. We will be competing with Europe by being the best, not by being the cheapest.I would love to have been a fly on the wall when Theresa May told union bosses that she was meeting their key demands not just with a promise but with a legal guarantee. But then she knew it was only right, because union members were the bedrock of leave voters across the country.And, I believe, we can get more in the next fortnight. A clear commitment to a once-in-a-generation investment into the Leave-voting areas that have long been starved of our fair shares — those former coal, iron and steel industrial heartlands, the unfashionable places, the areas still manufacturing. I think, as well, that union bosses and industrialists can be brought to act as advisers to the trade negotiations when we have left the EU, bringing their expertise into play to ensure a jobs-first Brexit for Britain.A country, proud and independent, standing on its own two feet, ­confident again in our democracy, bold enough to compete by being the best, British workers making high- quality products and delivering high-quality services.A country that says it will be the best by having better pay, conditions and a healthier environment than anyone  in Europe or worldwide.Is that not something to be confident in voting for, my fellow MPs  Let’s get on with it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cult of brexit remainer fading
story: I will try, but it is hard to see eye to eye with those who regard the .million who voted Out in  as pig- ignorant racists.Or to forgive Chancellor Phil Hammond for twisting Treasury data to undermine the British economy.I will simply wish him well in retirement at the earliest possible moment.Anna Soubry is a bit of a challenge too, but I will ­eventually find something nice to say.As for EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, even Her ­Eurosceptic Majesty would find little common ground with the man who vowed to punish her United Kingdom for daring to leave.But it will be cult-like Remainers who find it hardest to kiss and make up.Their hatred of Leavers has reached sectarian proportions.Astonishingly a poll found many would ban marriage outside the EU faith.Indeed, my old friendMatthew Parris insists Her Maj was wrong to suggest there is any common ground at all, because it might appear to endorse Theresa May’s dodgy deal.The Times sage has abandoned the Zen-like equilibrium which once made him ­compulsive reading. Along with the likes of megabucks Remainers Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson and PR guru Roland Rudd, he seems to think Brexiters are basically pond le.That theory should be buried forever after this weekend’s passionate plea from leading academic Sir Noel Malcolm for MPs to stop wrecking Brexit.Writing in the devoutly pro-EU Financial Times, this distinguished Fellow of All Souls, Oxford, spells out the essence of the Leave case: “Brexit is about sovereignty — and parliament must respect that.”“If the UK is now on the brink of a constitutional crisis,” he adds, “one major reason is that a signicant number of MPs still oppose any version of Brexit, and seek a second ­referendum solely for the sake of reversing the decision of the last one.”Sir Noel does not believe people voted Out because they were racist.“The most important reason was democracy,” he says.“They wanted to live under laws made by the people they elected. Immigration came second.What they objected to was a supranational government ­making some of their laws and lting all immigration controls on the inhabitants of  other countries.”Another Remainer fiction is that Brexiters are narrow-minded Little Englanders.Yet the Daily Mail found space for a German view that Brussels should stop “insulting Britain” and honour us as champions of peace in Europe.“Such blinkered and sour responses are wrong-headed,” says Alexander von Schoenburg, a senior editor of Germany’s biggest newspaper, Bild.“They ignore the great debt Germany and the whole ­Continent owes our friends across the Channel.“We must always remember that throughout your history, independence and sovereignty have been paramount.“Germany in particular should tread lightly when it comes to dealing with your proud nation. It was Great Britain that first stood up to Hitler in .And it was Britain that opened its doors to thousands of ­Jewish refugees fleeing certain death during the Holocaust.“Put simply, there would be no free Europe without you and the bloody sacrice you made to rescue the Continent.”This remarkable tribute ­follows a recent love letter to the UK from Germany’s next Chancellor calling for a friendly Brexit orce and an end to bitterness.It is now clear hardline Remainers have over-reached themselves. The worm has turned.Talk of a second referendum is dead and voters are on the warpath against MPs plotting to scupper Brexit in tomorrow’s Commons showdown.Brussels is in chaos over the Northern Ireland backstop.Michel Barnier has started muttering about new tech- nology to police post-Brexit ­frontiers — a UK idea initially dismissed as “magical thinking”.EU allies are breaking ranks to demand a decent deal — for their sake as much as ours.It is way past time now for Theresa May to scrap the backstop and tell Brussels exactly what she needs to get her deal through Parliament.“There is absolutely no truth in speculation that ­passengers are being advised not to book,” stormed Brittany Ferries as it announced plans to INCREASE services.Meanwhile, mischief-making aviation giant Airbus admits it was asked by Downing Street to warn – incredibly – that it would shut up shopBritain left without a deal.Project Fear is shameless.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: molly russell social media blame
story: Vulnerable Molly Russell faced a flood of self-harm images on Instagram and Pinterest — helping drive her to suicide.The sites haven’t done enough to stop a repeat of this tragedy.And the power of the web giants is only growing. We need action now.So well done Matt Hancock for threatening the nuclear option. He warns companies could be shut downthey continue to fuel a suicide epidemic.Britain must be a world leader in holding the tech Goliaths to account.No more kids should suffer Molly’s fate.MARTIAL law  Come off it.Claims that Britain will need military intervention in a No Deal Brexit are the most ridiculous fear-mongering yet.No Deal would be a challenge — but Britain would get through it and thrive.Panicked civil servants should listen to the Queen. title: this morning nta ally ross tv opinion
story: Six days a week now, This Morning hammers home the message its viewers are the most helpless, mollycoddled invertebrates on the planet.A form of le so useless that last November Dr Chris Steele, the show’s resident quack, genuinely felt the need to give us all bottom-wiping advice.“It’s a front-to-back action for women,” more of a hit-and-hope exercise for men.Infor this constant nannying, we pick up a phone once a year and gurgle: “You’re absolutely right. We are useless. Have a trophy.”And it’s a depressing cycle that will continue for as long as there are National Television Awards, live from The O.A ceremony where the categories may chop and change every year, but the stupidity remains ritualised.As well as getting all the usual winners though, viewers also had to endure a technical nightmare on Tuesday, where things went wrong — from the shambolic opening scenes right through to the unedited version of the closing credits: “With thanks to — Television Centre White City or just Television Centretoo long.”It’s always a case of fine margins, of course, at the NTAs, and the evening might have strayed into so-bad-it’s-good territorythe cameras had just focused on one of the Love Island gang when host Dermot O’Leary said: “Danny DeVito will be in Dumbo next year.”They didn’t, though. So a night bedevilled by sound issues, rotten acceptance speeches and foul Danny Dyer language was crowned by Special Recognition winner David Dimbleby eulogising the BBC and ordering us to be nicer to politicians, in a speech that could hardly be descri- bed as “mood capturing”.It’s the awards themselves though, that I know get viewers’ goats the most, starting, painful as it is to admit, with the fact perennial winners This Morning absolutely robbed Piers Morgan’s Good Morning Britain operation in the Daytime category.Given that Jack Whitehall’s Travels With My Father managed to scrape on to the Comedy shortlist, there’s also an argument that says Chunk, Charlotte Hawkins, Richard Arnold and Susanna Reid — who was styled quite magnicently on the night as Waitrose’s answer to Vicky Pattison — should have made that final five as well.Because almost no show made me laugh as loud or as regularly as Good Morning Britain did in .A glaring omission too in the TV Judge section — always won by David Walliams — which included X Factor’s Robbie Williams on the shortlist, but not Craig Revel Horwood, who didn’t take a two-week sabbatical in the middle of Strictly, cost the BBC £million or throw in his other half as part of the deal.The award that made a nonsense of the whole occasion though was Ant  Dec winning Best Presenters for the th time in a row, despite the presence of Bradley Walsh and Graham Norton on the shortlist, and the fact Ant spent far more weeks in rehab than he did in a TV studio.The mutual affection is touching in one way, of course, but it ultimately does neither them nor the NTAs any good at all and has robbed both of a glorious moment of redemption when they win the  award.Before that foregone conclusion takes place, please stay tuned to This Morning and sit tight until mid-March, when Dr Chris will be along with part II of his bottom-wiping masterclass: Flushing, FLU-SHING.Practially the only programme I watched at the weekend that wasn’t punctuated by uncontrollable sobbing fits from the participants was BBC’s landmark Holocaust documentary The Last Survivors.Men and women who are all in their late eighties and nineties now and understand that time is precious.When you’re a living part of history you also know facts are far more precious than tears.So in the words of the remarkable Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who avoided the Auschwitz gas chamber purely because she could play the cello: “I won’t give people the pleasure of seeing my emotions.”The very least we owe all of them is an audience. The Last Survivors is available on the BBC iPlayer and will probably be the most unforgettable  minutes of television you’ll watch all year.At approximately : hours, Sunday, Gemma Collins stumbled over while Dancing On Ice.The tectonic plates groaned a little on impact, the front row scattered like ten pins and there was a surge on the national grid as several million viewers went “click, rewind, play,” then “click, rewind, play,” again.In fact, by the time I’d stopped rewinding and playing, Gemma had “bounced back,”and Piers Morgan, no doubt angling for a Le Stories interview, had claimed it was “the gutsiest thing I’ve seen on a talent show” – probably since the days Piers himself was wedged in behind the judges’ desk on Britain’s Got Talent.It was an undeniably great television moment, though.A proper face plant, with a full Klinsmann snow plough to finish.The downside, obviously, is that it’s guaranteed she’ll be back next week, when Melody, Wes, James and the others will be performing to a Fairytale theme and Gemma will be clearing the B Fettercairn to Banchory road,ITV want to find a proper use for her.Click, rewind, play.Things remain cheerful as hell on EastEnders.Alfie Moon’s car has been discovered near some clfs and a policeman has the job of breaking the most awful news imaginable to Kat and the Slaters.“Considering the location and the evidence at hand, we would suggest you prepare yourself for the worst.”Big Mo: “You understand what they’re saying ”Yes, bloody Redwater’s getting a second series. Stay strong, viewers.Celebrity Coach Trip, Roxanne Pallett: “I knew as soon as Jedward got on the coach it was going to be fun.”The One Show, Matt Baker: “If you haven’t seen The Greatest Dancer yet, watch it on the iPlayer. It’s well worth it.”And Icons, Kathleen Turner: “Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and smash social barriers.”No, Charlie Chaplin used his films to try and make people laugh.Tell the BBC to try it some time.Good Morning Britain, Piers Morgan: “Every cloud. We lost the NTA, but I got a kiss off Gemma Collins.” Yeah, every cloud’s got a gigantic p***-storm.No one from Peaky Blinders bothering to turn up to the NTAs to thank: “The best fans a show could hope for.”Celebrity Coach Trip contestants Jedward ­providing the finest argument yet for theof a hard Irish border.Sheridan Smith’s accent doing the London to Doncaster trip in . seconds flat, on that Cleaning Up tosh.The Greatest Dancer’s pre-performance sob stories straying horribly close to moral blackmail territory.And E fly-on-the-wall moron Vogue Williams asking: “Is Gandhi the Dalai Lama ” in total ­ignorance of this remarkable man’s wisdom, serenity and even his landmark campaign for Dolce  Gabbana’s Light Blue fragrance . . .Martin Keown: “It should be a great spectacle, so sit back, hide behind the sofa and enjoy it.”Phil Thompson: “You never know what’s going to happen and that’s exactly what happened.”And Paul Merson: “If he was at Arsenal doing this, he wouldn’t be doing it.”.This week’s winner is the bellowing great Orca herself, Gemma Collins, and Sugar, from Total Drama Island.Sent in by Rich, of Lincolnshire. Picture research: Alfie Snelling.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “At the  Olympics, what birds were first released as a symbol of peace ” Georgina: “Eagle.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “What is the name of the monument in Trafalgar Square built in ­honour of Admiral Horatio Nelson ”Gemma: “Pass.”Ben Shephard: “Which British comedian ­presented the television programme Backchat with his father Michael ”Linda: “Jasper Carrott.”And Ben Shephard: “The Tartan Army is the nickname for fans of which national football team ” Najam: “Newcastle United.”Najam. A word . . .ITV’s The Paras: Men Of War, evenit needed three more episodes and better editing.BBC’s The Last Survivors. Tom Jones singing Cry To Me, with the talented Bethzienna Williams, on The Voice.The sudden, joyful NTA realisation the old bald bloke with the white beard in row A was Tim Lovejoy.And Celebrity Coach Trip guide Brendan Sheerin telling Jedward, Charlotte Crosby, Roxanne Pallett et al: “Today, you’re all going to a donkey sanctuary.” Well it’s about time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick timothy brady brexit vote
story: With the deadlock among MPs still not broken, nobody knows for sure what will happen.Theresa May says Brexit must go ahead on time. But she also says Britain will not leave the EU without a deal.And her deal — the only one on the table at this late stage — was defeated in the House of Commons by a record majority just two weeks ago.Tonight’s Brexit votes are not quite the final shoot-out between the dferent factions in Parliament. The Government has promised that MPs will vote soon on a new plan.Remainers and soft Brexit supporters in government are pushing to hold that vote as soon as possible.And MPs — backed by a Speaker who will rewrite any Commons rules to soften or stop Brexit — will force more votes on what happens next.Nevertheless, tonight’s votes do matter.One proposal comes from Yvette Cooper, a Labour MP.Her Yorkshire constituents voted to leave the EU by more than two to one and, during the election, she promised them she would “not vote to block Brexit.”Yet that is what her plan does:     MPs vote for her   amendment, they will be able to stop Brexit happening this year.Cooper has the support of several rebel Tories, soJeremy Corbyn whips his MPs to vote for it, she stands a good chance of getting her way.Caroline Spelman and Jack Dromey, Conservative and Labour, have an amendment that calls on the Government to avoid a no-deal Brexit.Dominic Grieve wants MPs to control the Commons timetable, allowing Parliament to vote on dferent ways of watering Brexit down.Labour want to present MPs with options that include, predictably, a second referendum.Despite drafting a manesto saying “Labour accepts the referendum result”, the Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer says in a second referendum he would campaign to overturn the result of the first.It is possible that none of these amendments might pass.Remainers and soft Brexiteers are ided about what should happen.Some want to delay Brexit, some want to tie us to European rules and regulations, and others want another referendum to stop it altogether.Evenno proposal wins a Commons majority, the votes cast by MPs will probably demonstrate that there is a majority to water down Brexit one way or another.For Brexit supporters, this is very dangerous indeed.Some believe they simply need to run down the clock and, in  days, we can leave without a deal.For Leavers who want a negotiated departure, this feels like a serious risk.But Leavers who favour no deal need to ask themselves, can they really be so sure they will get what they want With several Cabinet ministers, many more junior ministers and a Commons majority against no deal, it seems increasingly likely that MPs will ultimately find a way of stopping no deal.When they do, Brexit will only get softer and softer.This is why the amendment proposed by Graham Brady, a senior Conservative, is so important.His idea is to approve the Prime Minister’s original Brexit deal, but with the “backstop” removed.The backstop is hated by unionists, because to prevent barriers to trade between Ireland and Northern Ireland, it creates new barriers to trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.And it is hated by Leavers, because it ties the UK to the EU’s customs union, and Northern Ireland to EU single market rules.Brady wants MPs to vote simply for “alternative arrangements” to the backstop.By avoiding a specic proposal, he hopes the amendment can win a Commons majority and, in doing so, demonstrate to Brussels that the deal they struck with Theresa May can be ratied — but only without the backstop.Critics, largely Remainers, say this is impossible.But in the past week or so, Angela Merkel has questioned whether the backstop is such a good idea after all.The Polish foreign minister has suggested it should expire after five years. And the European Commission effectively conceded that in the event of no deal, they would use policy and technology to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.In other words, they proposed solutions they once dismissed as “unicorns” and “magical thinking” when they were suggested by the British — and which could render the backstop unnecessary.But this is not all. Some European officials have floated, in private, a more inventive solution: that the UK and Ireland should form a British Isles customs zone, with Britain compensating Ireland for any new friction in their trade with Europe.So it is clear: whatever Remainers claim, alternatives to the backstop are technically and politically feasible.Recognising this, the Brady amendment would give the Government one last chance to negotiate something better.Yet Tory Brexiteers say they might not vote for it. They fear the ambiguity of “alternative arrangements” could allow ministers to negotiate an even worse deal, perhaps tying the whole of the UK to the EU’s customs union and single market rules for good.They do not trust May, her advisers, or most of her Cabinet and demand a specic time limit on the backstop.Butthey vote down the Brady amendment, they will not get what they want, and are more likely to get what they fear.As the clock ticks on and bottoms get even squeakier, MPs will coalesce around a plan to stop a no-deal Brexit.The EU will have no reason to compromise, and Parliament will soften our departure by aligning us with more and more European laws.If Leavers vote against Brady, they will be shooting themselves not in one foot, and not even in both feet, but in the head.As the Commons debates the proposals today, Leavers need to start compromising with reality. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house graveyard garden spooks buyers price
story: Buyers have been spooked by more than  old headstones and tombs covering the front lawn of the three-bedroom house at North Lopham near Diss, Norfolk.The price of the Grade Two listed home has been slashed by more than £, to £, since it first went on the market last April.The house, which dates back to , was a chapel until it closed in  due to its dwindling congregation.It was snapped up by a property developer and has now been beautully converted into a trendy home with a ft by ft open plan double height living room and kitchen.Estate agents Bedfords are now hoping that buyers will overcome their fears about the graves and snap it up at its cut price.Emmerson Dutton, a partner at Bedfords office in Bury St Edmunds office, said: “I am sure that the gravestones have been a factor in putting off some buyers.“It is a very stylish property, but the activity levels around it have certainly been lower than we would expect.“I think the people who are concerned about the graves don’t go as far as asking for a viewing. We are not trying to hide the gravestones away so the details clearly show them.“But although the house still has the original two doors at the front, the main entrance is at the back via a driveway on the side.“It means that people don’t have to walk down the path between the graves into the house.“Also when you are inside the house, you are not really overlooking the graves because of the layout inside.“I am hoping that perhaps it might appeal to someone from outside the area.”Mr Dutton said the chapel had been bought and turned into a high-quality home with “a wonderful light-filled interior” by a local developer.The developer originally planned to live there before changing his mind and putting it on the market as he wanted to move nearer his childrens’ schools.It was originally up for sale at £, with a dferent agent before it was taken on by Bedfords, who cut the price to £, before cutting it again.Mr Dutton believes the house, which has a new roof and windows, is worth at least £, more than its price tag due to the quality of the conversion.He said: “It just seems buyers are put off which is such a shame as the cost of the conversion far outweighs the price it’s for sale for.“Someone is going to get a real bargain. It might be that once a year, on Halloween, it becomes an issue but most people could live with that.”It has , square feet of living space and underfloor heating with a castellated side extension still bearing the name “Wesleyan Day School.”The graveyard at the front is still owned by the church authorities on a -year lease, meaning they are responsible for its upkeep.Among the graves is a headstone belonging to Jon Cousins, a minister of a Methodist chapel in Diss who died  in .The master bedroom with an en suite bathroom is on the ground floor along with two further bedrooms, a utility room, and family bathroom.Downstairs is a kitchen with oak flooring and state of the art cabinets, an island, granite worktops and a range-style oven.The first floor has a galleried landing around three sides of the building which Bedfords say could be used as a playroom, study areas or hobby space.There is also plenty of built-in storage space and a good-sized garden at the rear with a double cart lodge.

title: gas field decade found north sea scotland british industry boost
story: The Glengorm field, east of Aberdeen, is described as the biggest gas discovery of its kind in a decade.Drilling found the equivalent of around  million barrels of oil could be recovered from the site -  about five per cent of the UKs annual gas demand.The astonishing find has been hailed as signicant by industry experts, who reckon the field could be producing gas within four to five years via existing rigs in the area.Glengorm - discovered by Chinese company CNOOC - is close to energy giant Totals Elgin-Franklin and Culzean fields.The gas is in a reservoir with high pressure and high temperatures, meaning it will be more costly to produce than other gas fields.But Kevin Swann, a senior analyst with the consultancy group Wood Mackenzie, said the scale of the reservoir would make it economically viable to extract.He told the BBC: There is a lot of hype around frontier areas like West of Shetland, where Total discovered the Glendronach field last year. But Glengorm is in the Central North Sea and this find shows there is still le in some of the more mature UK waters.The Oil and Gas Authority branded the discovery “very exciting news”.And Andy Samuel, chief executive of the regulator, said there is every chance of yet more signicant finds”.But environmental groups have slammed the find, saying the venture will contribute to climate change.They want energy firms to leave oil and gas in the ground and use renewable resources.Caroline Rance, from Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: Its a disgrace that oil and gas exploration is still going ahead in the seas off Scotland.Its high time our governments stopped supporting fossil fuel development, and get serious about planning a just transition away from this industry.Energy Minister Paul Wheelhouse said the announcement, highlights the signicant potential for oil and gas which still exists beneath Scotlands waters.He added: Scotlands offshore oil and gas industry has an important role to play with up to  billion barrels of oil equivalent remaining under the North Sea and in the wider basin and discoveries such as this help to support security of supply as we make the transition to a low carbon energy system.

story: She delivered a presentation to Cabinet colleagues on a detailed plan to tweak rules that would slash the amount taxpayers contribute to the bloated £ billion a year budget.Ms Mordaunt told weekly meeting - chaired by the Prime Minister - that the Government could then use the savings to boost NHS spending and “other domestic priorities”.Cabinet ministers also backed moves to use the foreign aid budget to support Britain’s Armed Forces and humanitarian missions.The strict rules by the OECD’s Development Assistance Committeemean millions of pounds of aid spending do not count towards the . per cent of national income target.Hundreds of millions of our aid spending is spent through private firms - such as the CDC Group.These contractors make profits, which are then invested back into foreign aid projects, but the rules bar these profits from being counted towards the . per cent target.Ms Mordaunt said changing the rules to allow this reinvested profit to count towards the target would free up millions of pounds for other departments by shaving the bloated aid budget.She said this would also allow her Department for International Developmentto “move from being a spending department to a fundraising department”.Ms Mordaunt told Cabinet that the . per cent “in its current form is unsustainable” but changing rules would help the foreign aid obligations become “less reliant” on the public purse.She launched a new consultation with charities, financial services, investors and the public about how to allocate more private money towards the foreign aid target.Ms Mordaunt said the review will also look into how money invested in saving and pension funds could deliver more s for UK investors.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nick clegg job fix facebook molly russell
story: The former Deputy Prime Minister, last seen being booted out by the voters of Sheffield Hallam, has re-emerged as Facebook’s Mr Fixit — the man tasked by its CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, with rescuing the reputation of the embattled internet firm.Having claimed that “I actually find the messianic Calornian new-worldy-touchy-feely culture of Facebook a little grating”, Sir Nick has duly installed himself in a £million mansion near San Francisco, ready to offer his expertise.Some people have been puzzled about why the world’s most powerful social media company, owner of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, would recruit a man whose main brush with online fame was an autotuned video of him apologising for betraying the public over tuition fees.In fact, Clegg and Zuckerberg are a match made in heaven. Both are powered by an inexorable sense of self-righteousness. And both have an awful lot of experience of saying sorry.The most recent example came when Sir Nick appeared on the BBC in the wake of the furore over the death of -year-old Molly Russell.It turned out, after she was found dead in her bedroom in December , that she had been viewing material online relating to depression, self-harm and suicide — material which was shockingly easy to find.As her father Ian Russell put it bluntly: “Instagram helped kill my daughter.”Sir Nick, to his credit, said all the right things about how the firm was determined to do more. But he also made the striking claim that it is sometimes better for Facebook and Instagram to keep suicide images online, because it helps other vulnerable young people get support.This after The Sun, on Saturday, found and flagged up multiple images appearing to normalise and even romanticise suicide, all within a few clicks. Many remained published for days, and a Facebook spokesman claimed they could be beneficial to users battling mental health issues.Sir Nick says the firm is following the advice from leading experts and charities. And it may well be doing the right thing. But this is the latest example of Facebook — and other social media giants in general — only acting to tackle a problem once it becomes impossible not to.Over the past decade, social media has come to dominate our lives. The latest research from Ofcom shows internet use rocketing among children and teenagers, with friendships and social lives increasingly run through screens and phones.And it is now clear that this great move online has been accompanied, for our children, by a staggering increase in mental health problems.The situation is particularly alarming when it comes to young women. The latest NHS data found that one in four of those aged  to  report having a mental health disorder — twice the rate among boys.In  alone, one in five US girls aged between  and  suffered a major depressive episode — one in five! Suicide rates for teenage girls, according to academic Jonathan Haidt, have risen by  per cent in the US and  per cent in the UK in a decade.This isn’t just about what happens on the internet. Those having problems online often tend to be experiencing problems offline too, such as bullying, harassment or broken families.More broadly, Haidt believes the “snowflake” phenomenon reflects that “helicopter parenting” leaves children less prepared to cope with shocks and dficulty. But the internet, and social media, are very clearly intensying those problems. And the big tech firms are still playing catch-up.The traditional argument from Silicon Valley is that it’s not their job to regulate human behaviour. They add that eventhey wanted to, there is simply too much out there.They are doing their best to crack down on inappropriate content, but it’s like trying to stem the tide. Behind the scenes — they insist — thousands of people are working day and night to detect and delete messages promoting terrorism, hatred, Holocaust denial and self-harm.But this argument just doesn’t wash. It’s very clear that, in the interests of their bottom lines, many of the big social media firms have long failed to put enough resources into detecting damaging content.Researchers have shown, for example, how following the recommended links from reputable YouTube content can lead to a carnival of horrors. News reports that segue into crackpot conspiracy theories and videos for toddlers that give way to horrendous scenes of a bloodied Minnie Mouse trapped in an escalator.Every day brings new horror stories, such as rival fans of royals Kate and Meghan using the Kensington Palace Instagram to send death threats to each other. Increasingly, online hate is triggering real-le violence. The slaughter of the Rohingya Muslims in Burma was, The New York Times said, “a genocide incited on Facebook”.Part of the reason that Zuckerberg has hired Clegg is to put his house in order. Clegg has talked the right talk about changing Facebook’s culture, and in particular doing more to tackle self-harm.He even says they might start paying more tax. ButZuckerberg’s answer to “how to fix the internet” is “hire Nick Clegg”, we have still got an awfully long way to go.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle national theatre beams arrives visit patron
story: Wearing towering £ Aquazzura heels, the Duchess of Sussex could barely contain her delight as she arrived for her “debut performance” as royal patron – having taken over from the Queen.Its believed the duchess - who recently revealed she is around six months pregnant - wore the same Very Matilde designer pumps for the debut as she donned during the engagement announcement with Prince Harry in November .The duchess was pictured in the towering pumps just days after a doctor told The Suns Fabulous Online of the risks of wearing high heels in pregnancy - saying a hard, straight fall could put a lot of pressure on her stomach which could damage the baby.Kensington Palace have said todays visit will allow the former actress to explore the organisations work, and meet some of the talented teams and apprentices working behind the scenes.During her visit, the duchess watched as people from neighbourhoods across London took part in a workshop in a rehearsal space.She also met with members of the Pericle Public Acts Company as well as apprentices from the National Theatre.The duchess also watched schoolchildren from Edith Neville Primary School in Camden perform War Horse during the engagement.The duchess was greeted by Rufus Norris, director of the National Theatre, who held a private meeting with her in December ahead of the patronage announcement earlier this month.Its thought Meghan - best known for playing Rachel Zane in the hit US legal drama series Suits - has an affinity with the National Theatre after spending a decade working as an actress in television.The duchess studied theatre and international relations at Northwestern University, Illinois, and volunteered at a performing arts after-school programme for children in underprivileged school districts in Los Angeles.Meghan, , is a strong believer in using the arts to bring people from dferent backgrounds and communities together - and her views chime with the National Theatres ethos of producing world class theatre with the aim of being as inclusive, erse and national as possible.The - season saw the National Theatre stage  productions at the South Bank,  across the UK, three in the West End and six internationally.Its UK-wide learning and participation programme supports young peoples creative education through performance and writing programmes like Connections, New Views and Lets Play.The National Theatre extends its reach through digital programmes including NT Live, which broadcasts some of the best of British theatre to over , venues in  countries, and the free streaming service On Demand In Schools, used by nearly % of UK state secondary schools.

title: mum girl born half arm told cover up
story: Gracie Morgans mum moved the two-year-old after hearing the little boy say he was frightened by her small left arm.But the boys mother then came over - and said Gracies arm shouldnt be so obvious because it was scaring other children.Gracie had been wearing a short sleeved dress at the soft play centre in Llanelli, West Wales.Mum-of-four Sarah said: Gracie was happily playing when a little boy started to take an interest in her small arm.This happens a lot and Im not very comfortable with people staring but children are curious and thats OK.But then the little boy started to say he was scared so I took Gracie and moved her to play with her brothers in a dferent part of the playground.Thats when the boys mother came over. She said I shouldnt make Gracies arm so obvious because it was scaring the children.I was so angry I just gathered up the kids and left. I didnt trust myself to respond.Nurse Sarah, , said it isnt the first time she has had cruel comments made about Gracie in public.She said: Ive started to dread going to play groups and soft play because of the negative attention.One time an older boy was circling Gracie and pointing and laughing while his parents just looked on.People dont know what to say. I dont knowthey feel awkward but its cruel to allow that bullying and its the parents I blame not the kids.Gracie, of Llwynhendy, near Llanelli, lives with mum Sarah, dad Gareth Morgan,  and her brothers Cai, nine, Codi, five, and Alfie, three.Sarah added: At the moment Grace is young and doesnt understand. Nothing stops her and I want her to always be that way.Shell hold a crisp packet between her feet and use her right hand to eat. Or she puts a yoghurt under her little stump and has the spoon in her right hand.She overcomes everything that I might have considered a challenge before.To us she is absolutely perfect in every way.Gracies family are fundraising to have a bionic prosthetic arm made so she can continue to live as independently as possible as she gets older.

title: couple engaged greggs postman proposes sausage roll
story: True romantic Nick Sawyer, , proposed to partner of two years Carolyn Bennett in a branch of the bakery in Wolverhampton on Sunday.Carolyn, , had lived opposite Nick for a decade but it was only after eight years that he finally plucked up the courage to ask her out.Nick, , said he had considered waiting for a more appropriate moment to hand over the diamond ring, which he had bought just minutes before from a jeweller next door, but decided the time was right.The dad-of-two and grandad-of-three said: I had just been in the jeweller next door, and afterwards we went into Greggs and had a cup of tea and a sausage roll.We had talked about marriage, so it was just a case of when the proposal was going to happen.I knew Carolyn didn’t want a big party, so while we were in Greggs I pulled out the ring and said ‘shall I put it on now ’I didn’t actually get down on one knee, but she was still very happy.Teaching assistant Carolyn added: Weve been going to Greggs a lot recently – its friendly and reasonably priced.We had discussed getting married, but I wasn’t expecting it quite then.Nick got the ring out while we were sat in Greggs and asked meI wanted to wait, but I said I wanted to have it now!Its about the two of us, we just wanted to do it for us and so that was how we did it.It made us realise you’ve just got to go for it. It was always the plan it was just getting round to it.It was a lovely proposal – it was emotional.Carolyn said that she and her hubby-to-be are looking forward to their future – but haven’t set a date for their nuptials yet.She said: Nick is a calm and kind man, but Im biased obviously.Were looking forward to our le together and to be with each other.

title: moment dog bit toddler child gate
story: Isabelle Binns, aged one, from Lincolnshire was pulled with such force as she stroked the devil dog that the gate came off its hinges.The terrying incident happened while the youngster was staying at her grandmother Julie Booth’s home in Woods Terrace in Gainsborough, Lincolnshire, on Friday, January .Isabelle placed her hand near a safety gate only for the dog to grab her arm with its teeth.The gate fell on the dog and Julie was quickly on hand to rescue the baby, who was left with five deep puncture wounds to her arm following the attack from fostered golden retriever, who was staying at the home while it waited to be sheltered.The distressing video was caught on camera by the home CCTV and has been shared to Lincolnshire Live by Isabelle’s father, Michael Binns.“My partner and I went out on Thursday night so we left our daughter with her grandma,” the -year-old said.“My partner [Cha] got the call from her mum as I was back at work as a LIVES first aid responder.The dog dragged her through the safety gate and bit into her arm. She was used as a the battering ram for the safety gate.“My daughter was screaming the house down, I can imagine it was quite frightening for a one-year-old.”After learning what had happened, the worried parents were keen to make sure their child was ok.He added: My partner went round said her arm was punctured and bleeding. I had to leave quickly and cleaned it up before the ambulance got there.”The little girl was taken to hospital and has since been given the all clear.The dog has since been put down by the company who arranged the fostering, according to Mr Binns.He said: “It was a golden retriever so it was quite a surprise as they are usually quite nice.Luckily enough she doesn’t seem traumatised. Her auntie came round with a poodle the next day and Isabelle went straight up to it and stroked it. I don’t knowit will be dferentit is a golden retriever.”Mr Binns has been left unhappy after claiming the police officer who attended said that the dog didn’t need to be put down, but just left with owners away from families - a comment Mr Binns says is absolutely shocking.Lincolnshire Police have confirmed officers have attended the incident but have yet to comment on the claims made about the police officer.A spokesperson for EMAS confirmed paramedics were sent to the scene.“We received a call at .am on January  to a medical emergency in a private address in Gainsborough.We sent a crewed ambulance and one patient was taken to Scunthorpe General Hospital.”

title: emiliano sala plane wreckage found as two seat cushions discovered in channel
story: The Air Accidents Investigation Branchsaid the cushions are likely to have been from the Piper Malibu plane which vanished last Monday.Cardf City striker Sala and British pilot Dave Ibbotson, from Scunthorpe, are missing and presumed dead.The discovery was made by French investigators on a beach near Surtainville on the French coast.An underwater search is now set to take place as search and rescue teams look to recover the aircraft wreckage.An AAIB spokesman said: On the morning of Monday  January, we were advised by the Bureau d’Enquêtes  d’Analyses , the French safety investigation authority, that part of a seat cushion had been found on a beach near Surainville on the Cotentin Peninsula.A second cushion was found in the same area later that day.From a preliminary examination we have concluded that it is likely that the cushions are from the missing aircraft.We have now identied a priority underwater search area of approximately four square nautical miles.The fresh search is set to start this weekend due to dficult weather conditions expected over the coming days.Investigators expect the underwater trawl to last three days.The cushions are first wreckage to be found from the missing plane following a huge search of the English Channel.The Cardf-bound plane disappeared after taking off from Nantes Airport in France at around .pm last Monday.The Argentinian striker was set to be unveiled as Cardf Citys club record signing the next day after completing a £ million transfer from Nantes.The aerial search for the wreckage was ended by Guernsey Police last Thursday after three days of scouring the English Channel.Salas family has since pledged to launch their own private search and received backing from football stars including Lionel Messi and Gonzalo Higuain.His sister Romina said earlier this week: We will find a way to restart the search. title: theresa may brexit vote house of commons
story: Brexiteer MPs backed the PMs pledge to rewrite the deal she thrashed out with the EU in a last-ditch bid to get it over the line.Pro-Brexit Tories gave Mrs May a leline by backing an amendment tabled by Sir Graham Brady which calls for the Irish backstop to be dropped from the deal.The victory came in a dramatic turnaround just two weeks after her deal looked dead in the water following a humiliating Commons defeat.And in a double boost, the PM saw off an attempt by Labour to legally delay our exit date and rule out No Deal - widely seen as a backdoor bid to block Brexit altogether.The defeat of the motion tabled by Yvette Cooper and backed by Jeremy Corbyn is a huge blow to the so-called peoples vote campaign pushing for a second referendum.But a cross-party amendment speaking out against No Deal did succeed - as seven Labour rebels defied Jeremy Corbyn to vote for it, balancing out the eight Tories who opposed it.Speaking after the end of the voting, Mrs May insisted that No Deal was not off the table but vowed to work with senior MPs across the parties to build support for her deal.She said: Tonight a majority of honourable members have said they would support a deal with changes to the backstop.Combined with measures to address concerns over Parliament’s role in the negotiation of the future relationship and commitments on workers’ rights, in law where need be, it is now clear that there is a route that can secure a substantial and sustainable majority in this house for leaving the EU with a deal.We will now take this mandate forward and seek to obtain legally binding changes to the withdrawal agreement that deal with concerns on the backstop while guaranteeing noto a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. My colleagues and I will talk to the EU about how we address the house’s views.As I said this afternoon, there is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy.But in contrast to a fortnight ago, this house has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement.Now MPs have signalled they want “alternative arrangements” to the hated Northern Ireland backstop, then she can tell the EU thatthey make the change, Parliament is almost certain to sign it off in the coming weeks.Mrs May will speak to EU leaders today and the rest of the week - and could dash to Brussels for emergency talks too to thrash out a compromise.Jean-Claude Juncker has already ruled it out, but the PM could go around him to talk to the heads of the other EU states.If they manage to get a change, she will then give MPs another vote on her deal within weeks.If not, the PM will probably tell her MPs it’s her deal or nothing, having fought with the EU as much as possible but to no avail.MPs who fear crashing out could then turn around at the last minute and back the deal.Responding, Jeremy Corbyn agreed for the first time to attend talks on Brexit at  Downing Street.He said: The Prime Minister must now face the reality that No Deal is not an option. I will meet the Prime Minister and others from across Parliament to find a sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country.Boris Johnson hailed the PMs victory, saying the result was “clear unambiguous good news” and a “huge victory for Britain”.The Tory big hitter said: “The PM now has a mandate from Parliament that the backstop, the thing that keeps us locked in the single market, the customs union, has to come out.“Parliament has very clearly said there has to be a change. I hope our friends in Brussels will listen and make that change.Odds of the PMs deal getting passed shortened as a delay to Article  became less likely.Opening the debate this afternoon, Mrs May hinted at support for a new Brexit plan dreamed up by an unlikely alliance of Leavers and Remainers from across the Conservative party.The proposal, dubbed the Malthouse compromise after Housing Minister Kit Malthouse, would see an extended transition period designed to avoid chaos even in the event of a No Deal outcome.Mrs May said: While there are obviously details that need to be worked through, the fact that leading figures from dferent sides of the argument are coming together to develop proposals shows how much progress has been made over the past few weeks.Her commitment to fixing the backstop drew praise from top Brexiteers, including Jacob Rees-Mogg who said: May I thank her for her very clear assurances that the withdrawal agreement text will be re-opened and that she will be considering what has been called the Malthouse compromise.Kevin BarronRonnie CampbellRosie CooperJim FitzpatrickCaroline FlintRoger GodsfStephen HepburnKate HoeyJohn MannDennis SkinnerLaura SmithGareth SnellGraham StringerAnother  Labour MPs apparently abstainedThe DUPs Nigel Dodds added: She can be assured of our support in trying to find a solution which avoids any hard border on the island of Ireland but also avoids any borders within the UK.A meeting of the hardline European Research Group agreed to back the Brady motion - If you want Brexit, you have to vote for Brexit.Before todays debate, Business Minister Richard Harrington issued an extraordinary public warning to Mrs May not to take Britain out of the EU without a deal.After a crushing defeat a fortnight ago, she has won a vote sending her back to Brussels with a firm mandate to demand more from the Brexit deal.The EU can stonewall all it likes. title: eu theresa may brexit jump out window ireland
story: Simon Coveney snfed that the British government was being unreasonable for trying to change the hated Northern Ireland backstop - even though MPs have shown they simply wont agree to it.It Tusk’s called on the UK to “clary its intentions with respect to its next steps as soon as possible”.But in a testy exchange, Mr Raab, who quit over Mrs May’s Brexit deal last year,  told MPs on the after Brexit.And that he kept details of the dinner confidential at his request.But later on details of the dinner emerged in the papers, and the Irish Taoiseach commented on them.“It was simply not what I discussed or what I proposed, Mr Raab said.Elsewhere he also accused the Irish government of taking a “trenchant line” on the backstop.And the strong positions taken by the Government mean it will be hard to find a “ladder to climb down”.Mr Raab  insisted that a way forward for the Irish border based on checks away from the frontiersneeded and “good will” from both sides.He pointed out that Michel Barnier himself was looking at ways to protect the integrity of the single market in the event that Britain left without a deal in March.“If it can be done in  months, it must be possible to be done in two years,” he argued.The Council chief vowed the bloc “will continue our preparations for all outcomes, including a no-deal scenario”.Earlier, in a private phone call, top Eurocrat Jean-Claude Juncker told Mrs May the deal cant be rewritten.And German MEP Manfred Weber, a close ally of Angela Merkel, claimed Gibraltar would be at riskBrexit talks restarted.He said: If there is now a unilateral attempt to reopen the agreement, the consequence will be that not just the backstop has to be renegotiated then the Gibraltar question, the question of how much money Britain has to pay for exiting, the question of citizens rights will have to be renegotiated.If we reopen, then everything will be reopened. And to be honest, I dont see much sense in that.Emmanuel Macron insisted the current deal is the best possible and said it was not renegotiable.EU bosses have repeatedly said the -page withdrawal agreement thrashed out in November cant be changed.They claim any tweaks must be confined to the attached political declaration, which is not legally binding.Today Mrs May told the Commons she would seek a signicant and legally binding change to the withdrawal agreement.The PM added: Negotiating such a change will not be easy - it will involve re-opening the withdrawal agreement, a move for which I know there is limited appetite among our European partners.But I believe that with a mandate from this house, I can secure such a change in advance of our departure from the EU.British officials believe the EU will agree to new talks to avoid a No Deal outcome which would harm the continent.

title: brexit compromise plan c theresa may backstop
story: Leaders of the party’s two warring tribes have come together to call on the PM to accept a new plan and unite Conservatives.It replaces the unpopular Irish backstop with a dferent one, based on ‘max fac’ new technology to keep the border open instead of having to follow EU rules for years.At the same time, the Brexit transition will be extended to almost three years until December .But its major flaw is it is bitterly opposed by Brussels, after the EU bosses dismissed technological solutions to the border dilemma last year “magical thinking”.The PM told the Commons that the idea – dubbed Plan C – is “a serious proposal that we’re engaging with sincerely and positively”.But she refused to fully commit to adopting it, instead saying it was only one of three options that she is mulling over taking back to Brussels.In an extraordinary blow to the PM’s personal authority, it emerged that several mid-ranking ministers have been plotting for days behind her back to devise it.During a secret meeting with Mrs May on Monday, Brexiteer leader Steve Baker and ex-Education Secretary Remainer and Nicky Morgan implored her to accept it and propose the plan as the Government’s policy.But the PM refused, saying she needed more time to think it through.It was drawn up by Housing Minister Kit Malthouse, a Leaver, and became known as the ‘Malthouse Compromise’.He was helped by another minister, former Remain campaigner Robert Buckland, who is the Solicitor General.A second element of their plan is to negotiate a basic ‘no deal’ deal with the EUtherethere is still no agreement with Brussels by the time Britain leaves on March .Under their proposition for it, the UK would keep paying the EU the same annual contributions as now, of £bn a year, until December  to avoid a clf edge for businesses.But the EU also opposes that, as it means Brussels won’t get its full £bn orce cheque, and there is to Irish border backstop.The plan won the support of arch Euroscpetic Jacob Rees-Mogg and his hardline European Research Group of around  Tory MPs.It was also backed by the DUP, whose  MPs are propping up Mrs May’s minority government, in a clear sign it could win a Commons majority.It came just hours after Business Minister Richard Harrington gave Downing Street an ultimatum — saying he could quit unless the PM gave ‘rebels’ a say by the middle of February.He stormed: “If she is prepared to give that irrevocable undertaking - which means at the despatch box or a similar instrument - many of us feel ‘Well, OK for the sake of everything, we will give her two weeks’. But that is it.”Sources claimed both Mr Harrington and Defence Minister Tobias Ellwood were on the verge of resigning to ensure the ‘Cooper-Boles’ amendment to delay Brexit wins a majority.But Mr Ellwood ruled it out before the votes took place.Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd warned No two weeks ago that up to forty Ministers could quit unless they were allowed to back Cooper-Boles.She last week refused three times to rule out resigning.But the Chancellor intervened before the weekend to urge ‘Remain’ Ministers to realise the debate wasn’t ‘High Noon’ – and “there will be other opportunities for Parliament to express its view”.Mrs May said: “We will bring a revised deal back to this House for a second meaningful vote as soon as we possibly can.“If we have not brought a revised deal back to this House by Wednesday February  we will make a statement and again table an amendable motion for debate the next day.” The Ulster unionist party’s leader Arlene Foster said: “We believe it can uny a number of strands in the Brexit debate including the views of remainers and leavers.“It also gives a feasible alternative to the backstop proposed by the European Union.”But Brussels roundly rejected the Malthouse Compromise and insisted there can’t be a transition period unless Britain signs up to the backstop.EU Parliament Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt told The Sun: “The European Parliament won’t give its consent to a weakened Withdrawal Agreement.“The deal we have is a fair compromise and cannot be re-negotiated. This is simply ditching the backstop in exchange for an extra year of transition period.”And the EU commission also poured cold water on the idea the bloc would green light a transition period without the UK accepting the whole deal.A spokesman said: “The transitional period is linked to the Withdrawal Agreement.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit backstop news latest theresa may brussels
story: The PM has vowed to fix the Irish backstop after uniting her party in last nights crunch Commons vote.But Eurocrats have insisted the existing deal cant be rewritten - setting up a huge bust-up between Britain and the EU.No is braced for a firefight as they scramble to convince Brussels to give ground with just two months left before Brexit.And Brexiteers warned the EU that it risks causing a No Deal outcome by refusing to compromise.This evening Mrs May will confront chief Eurocrat Donald Tusk in a crunch phone call.After winning support for a plan to ditch the backstop proposal - designed to keep the Irish border open - the PM promised MPs shed play hardball with Brussels.Mrs May told the Commons today she wont back down on her red lines of taking Britain out of the EU customs union and ending open-doors migration.The PM said: The plan that was set out last night shows that we can get a substantial and sustainable majority in this house.And she ridiculed Remainer efforts to rule out No Deal without saying what should happen instead - saying: Last night the house did vote to reject No Deal but that cannot be the end of the story. You cant just vote to reject No Deal, you have to vote for a deal.Now MPs have signalled they want “alternative arrangements” to the hated Northern Ireland backstop, then she can tell the EU thatthey make the change, Parliament is almost certain to sign it off in the coming weeks.Mrs May will speak to EU leaders today and the rest of the week - and could dash to Brussels for emergency talks too to thrash out a compromise.If they manage to get a change, she will then give MPs another vote on her deal within weeks.If not, the PM will probably tell her MPs it’s her deal or nothing, having fought with the EU as much as possible but to no avail.MPs who fear crashing out could then turn around at the last minute and back the deal.But the EU has hit back - claiming its not possible to impose legally binding changes on the existing deal.Frances Europe minister Nathalie Loiseau said: Time is running out. The withdrawal agreement that is on the table is the best possible agreement. Let us not reopen it.And Germanys Heiko Maas claimed the current deal is the best and only solution for an orderly withdrawal.The EUs Brexit envoy Michel Barnier added: The EU institutions remain united, and we stand by the agreement that we have negotiated with the UK.In a furious rant, Irish deputy PM compared Mrs May to someone saying, Give me what I want or Ill jump out of the window.A Downing Street source admitted there would be a clash with the EU but insisted there would be space for compromise later this week.The source said: We always knew the next  hours would be a firefight and they’ll say ‘no, no no’.We’ll see what happens after that. It’s a positive day but only the start of what will be an incredibly challenging process.”Brexiteers warned Brussels thatthey dont agree to fresh talks on the deal, they risk Britain crashing out of the EU without a deal on March .Jacob Rees-Mogg told talkRADIO: If they think that the withdrawal agreement is not negotiable, then we must leave without an agreement.Ex-minister Greg Hands added: Brussels is risking a hard Brexit.And Dominic Raab said: The balls now in the EUs court - theyve got to decide.Speaking in the Commons, Mark Harper warned fellow Brexit backers to give the Prime Minister space to get concessions out of the EU.He told MPs: Theyre not going to crumble tomorrow - were going to have to hold our nerve.The backstop is hated by Brexiteers because they fear it will leave Britain trapped in the customs union permanently.They want to see it replaced by technical measures which can carry out automatic checks on goods travelling between Northern Ireland and Republic.Last night the anti-backstop amendment tabled by senior Tory Sir Graham Brady passed through the Commons by  votes.At the same time MPs voted against a motion from Yvette Cooper which would have taken No Deal off the table.But the PM has promised them another vote on the way forward on Valentines Day where Remainers could restart their anti-Brexit campaign.

title: brexit second referendum peoples vote
story: Remainers are worried that a second referendum could be off the table in the wake of last nights Commons showdown.Theyre now gearing up for another push next month - but fear that could be the final chance to delay Brexit and secure a so-called peoples vote.Remain campaigners last night piled in behind a wrecking amendment tabled by Labours Yvette Cooper.But the motion, which would have seen Brexit pushed backBritain is heading for No Deal, was defeated by  votes.Pro-EU Tory Anna Soubry lamented: We’ve come closer to crashing out.The odds of a second referendum have slipped to   in the wake of the vote, from   at the beginning of this week, according to Ladbrokes.The Remainers are now pinning their hopes on a Valentines Day debate when the PM will give MPs another chance to have their say on the way forward.A senior source from one of the anti-Brexit campaigns told The Sun: It was a bad night - its worrying that we didnt have the numbers to extend Article .I think February  is the last chance saloon now.Brexit backers also claimed the result of last nights votes showed a rerun of the  vote isnt going to happen.Ex-minister Greg Hands said today: Support for a second referendum is so low amongst MPs that nobody even bothered to put it to the vote.Other Remainers insisted the campaign isnt dead and vowed to secure a victory next month.A Lib Dem source said: A handful of Labour MPs got the Tories out of a tight spot.But it was a pyrrhic victory - were just going to end up back at square one after the PMs macabre tour of Europe. Well try again on February .And former Cabinet minister Peter Hain, a backer of the Peoples Vote campaign, added: In two weeks the Prime Minister willto Parliament, and MPs should then reject a No Deal Brexit and instead support a people’s vote.After her victory last night, Theresa May is planning to head to Brussels to demand changes to the withdrawal agreement.

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
