But it could all fall down around her ears within days. So what actually happened on Tuesday night  MPs held a string of House of Commons votes on what the Prime Minister should do next, two weeks after her deal suffered a record -vote defeat. And she did better than expected. MPs blocked a bid to delay Brexit beyond  March - and instead backed her plan to re-open talks with the EU on the -page Brexit deal, including the Irish backstop. However, the rare glimmer of hope could soon flicker out because within minutes, the EU said the deal is NOT up for renegotiation. There is also more woe for her further down the track, because MPs rejected the prospect of a No Deal Brexit. It all means that, with just  days left until we leave the EU, talks are still deadlocked. The deadlocks just moved from London to Brussels. Here is a simple summary of the  key moments from tonight, and what they mean.  MPs have finally agreed on something about Brexit. Two weeks after Theresa Mays deal suffered an all-time record defeat, they rallied round an idea. MPs voted - for an amendment by Tory Sir Graham Brady which says theyll accept the deal - IF the Prime Minister rewrites it to change the Irish backstop. And crucially, she was backed by  of the  Tory rebels who defeated her last time. That suggests thatshe gets what she wants - a BIG- she could win a final meaningful vote in two weeks time. As recently as Monday, top Tory Brexiteers like Jacob Rees-Mogg were refusing to back the Brady amendment. But Mrs May won them round by promising solid legal changes, and looking at alternative proposals, a time limit and a unilateral exit clause. She told MPs: There is limited appetite for such a change in the EU and negotiating it will not be easy. But in contrast to a fortnight ago this House has made it clear what it needs to approve a withdrawal agreement.”   EU chiefs slapped down the vote less than  minutes after it happened. EU Council President Donald Tusk said - again - that he WONT reopen talks on the -page Brexit deal. Instead hes only offering to talk about the much smaller political declaration, which doesnt include the backstop. That leaves talks just as deadlocked as before. The deadlocks just moved from London to Brussels. An EU spokesman said: The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement. And the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation. If Brussels doesnt blink, peace in Westminster looks short-lived. And we could face a revolt against Theresa May all over again February . In a major but only symbolic move, MPs ordered Theresa May to reject a no deal Brexit. The amendment, which was by Tory MP Caroline Spelman and Labours Jack Dromey, passed by just eight votes.  voted to back the amendment, and  voted against. It doesnt require the government to do anything legally but it shows clearly the feeling of the Commons. And it lays down a marker for what happens nextTheresa May doesnt have any success with the EU. When she comes back to MPs on February , that feeling against a No Deal Brexit could turn into action.  Paradoxically, despite voting to reject No Deal, MPs also blocked a move that could have prevented it. The House of Commons rejected an amendment by Labour MP Yvette Cooper,  votes to , to extend the  March date of leaving the EUthere was no progress by February . The shock -vote majority was a crushing disappointment for Remainers who widely expected to block a damaging No Deal. So what do the two conflicting results mean Basically, MPs agree there should not be a No Deal Brexit. But they cant decide on how to block it.  The pound fell after MPs defeated a bid to delay Brexit. Sterling fell .% to the days low of .. It shows markets are still jittery about the prospect of a No Deal Brexit, which with  days to go, remains very, very real.  Jeremy Corbyn has agreed to meet Theresa May to try and break the Brexit deadlock. The Labour leader repeatedly refused to meet the Prime Minister until she ruled out no deal Brexit . But after Parliament voted to reject no deal, Mr Corbyn said he would meet with the PM - even though the vote was only symbolic. “I will meet the prime minister and others from across Parliament to find a sensible Brexit solution that works for the whole country, he said. “That solution should be based around Labour’s alternative plan of a customs union with a U.K. say, a strong single market relationship and a cast iron guarantee on workers’ rights, consumer standards and environmental protections.”  Theresa May had been expected to suffer a defeat at the hands of Tory rebels. But she was left more secure, partly because she was backed by Labour ones. For example,  Labour MPs backed the Brady amendment. If theyve voted against, it would have still passed but by just a whisker. Meanwhile  Tory Remainers including Anna Soubry and Kenneth Clarke backed the plan by Yvette Cooper to delay Brexit. But  Labour MPs balanced them out by opposing Coopers plan - the majority of whom represent Leave-voting consituencies including Caroline Flint and Laura Smith as well as long term Brexiteers Ronnie Campbell and Kate Hoey. A further  Labour MPs abstained including Ruth Smeeth, Melanie Onn and Gloria De Piero who represent Leave-voting seats.  The message from tonight is weve had a string of contradictory messages - and no certain future for Brexit. story: NewsCorbyn blasts Theresa Mays Brexit in furious PMQs - just minutes before compromise talksLabours leader is meeting the Prime Minister from pm today to solve the Brexit deadlock - but with  days to go, the pair have never looked more idedShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video corbyn-and-may-at-pmqs-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Jeremy Corbyns Brexit compromise talks with Theresa May look to be in tatters after a furious PMQs clash.The Labour leader will meet the Tory Prime Minister at pm today to find a way out of the national crisis. But  days before Brexit, the pair were as ided as ever in a furious exchange at Prime Ministers Questions. Mrs May refused to budge on her red lines and accept Mr Corbyns demand for a customs union with the EU. Meanwhile Mr Corbyn said it was very clear any deal will need exactly the customs union shes rejected. Despite supposedly uniting to find the way forward, the pair dug in their heels even deeper in todays clash. The PM mocked her Labour rival and Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry for not listening to her answers. And she claimed he didnt have a coherent Brexit plan of his own. Mrs May is heading back to the EU to reopen talks on her -page Brexit deal, including the Irish backstop.But the EU have already slapped down that request by saying the deal is not up for negotiation. Labours leader demanded today: Which of her red lines are going to change  And the PM would not say. Mrs May is demanding the Irish backstop, which could lock the UK in EU customs rules, is replaced with alternative arrangements. She claimed these arrangements could include mutual recognition of trusted trader schemes. But Mr Corbyn retorted: None of that was very clear to me, I dont know about anyone .  Mrs May also said she was seeking a unilateral exit mechanism or a time limit on the backstop - despite the EU flatly rejecting both ideas.And she refused to rule out a No Deal Brexit - despite MPs voting to reject the prospect of one last night. She said: Last night the House did vote to reject no deal - but that cannot be the end of the story. You cant just vote to reject no deal, you have to vote for a deal otherwise you leave with no deal.  The PM accused Jeremy Corbyn of not having a coherent policy - questioning whether his desire for a strong single market relationship would mean accepting EU blocks on state aid. Mr Corbyn said she had possibly, temporarily united the ided Tories - but added: Shes got to move on from the red lines she put down in the first place. Changes to the backstop alone will not be sufficient.  Businesses and trade unions are very clear that any solution must involve a customs union and the strongest possible relationship with the single market. But the Prime Minister pointed out MPs had voted to approve her deal - IF she replaces the backstop. He put forward a proposal last night... and his proposal was rejected by this House, she raged. He has no plan for Brexit, no good plan for our economy, and no plan for our country.Mr Corbyn will sit down with Theresa May for talks this afternoon in a bid to secure Labour demands on Brexit .The Labour leader, who boycotted earlier talks, said he was ready to discuss a “sensible” approach to Brexit after MPs voted to rule out no deal.  But the Prime Minister’s hopes of securing concessions from Brussels in time to avoid crashing out on March  appeared remote. EU chiefs underlined their opposition to reopening the withdrawal agreement. On Tuesday night MPs backed a plan, the Brady amendment, which forces the PM toto Brussels to try to negotiate “alternative arrangements” to the controversial Irish border backstop. She is expected to jet out to Brussels later this week. But her Brexit secretary, Steve Barclay, was unable to say what the “alternative” involved after being asked five times. “That’s what we’re exploring. There are a number of options,” he said.  And with just  days to go until Brexit Day he refused to “get into the technicalities” of how the plan would work. Despite last night’s victory the PM has never appeared more boxed-in. Fears mounted over whether the Brexiteers were planning to deliberately run down the clock - so that the UK would crash out without a deal. With MPs wondering who would blink first, the EU remained staunchly opposed to re-opening the orce deal. The head of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani, said the other EU states were standing firm. “The  governments remain united over Brexit. I hope we can avoid a hard Brexit. It is dficult to imagine we can renegotiate a deal that has been already approved by EU member states.”

story: NewsAmber Peat inquest: Girl, , found hanged was scared to go home from schoolAmber was found hanged in bushes three days after she went missing from her home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, an inquest has heardShareBySophie Evans:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAmber Peat was sometimes concerned about going home, an inquest has heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA missing -year-old girl who was found hanged was sometimes concerned about going home from school, an inquest has heard. Amber Peat was found sitting in the library, filled with worry, on one occasion after losing the belt from her coat, the hearing was told. Teacher Joanne Holland described how she had to call the youngsters mum because she was scared of going home and getting told off. During the phone conversation, Mrs Holland assured Ambers mother: We will find it, Nottinghamshire Coroners Court heard this week. She was worried about going home because she had lost the belt off her coat, the teacher told the court, according to the BBC. She basically said she was scared she was going to get told off. I had to phone home and tell mum, It really is fine, we will find it.   The encounter happened at the end of the school day, it was said. Amber was found hanged in  three days after she went missing from her home, following a row with her mum over household chores. The court has heard the argument was about cleaning a cool box, which was used to store food on a recent family holiday in Cornwall, where the youngster had hatched plans to run away with her cousin. Ambers mother Kelly Peat heard the front door slam shut shortly after the dispute at around .pm on May , , at the home in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, the inquest had been told. A passer-by saw somebody of Ambers description enter a hedgerow area near the address around  minutes later, it was said.  Up to  police staff were involved in the search for the missing youngster, before her body was tragically recovered on June . Speaking at the inquest, Mrs Holland, an ex-form tutor of Amber, described how the schoolgirl often tried to get attention. The teacher said she felt this could be because the student didnt get as much attention at home as would be considered normal. She recalled the youngsters habit of leaving an item behind after form time, so she couldto the classroom to retrieve it. She said she liked walking into a room filled with older students. Obviously the older students, because she was small and cute, were like, aww, look at Amber and she would love that, said Mrs Holland.  The teacher had been Ambers form tutor at Tibshelf Community School, but the pupil left the school before the end of her first year. Instead, she moved to Queen Elizabeth School in Mansfield . Another teacher has told the inquest that she didnt want to move. Before she vanished from her home before her death, the teenager had got into trouble for drinking Cherryade without permission. She had a history of running away, and Mrs Peat only called police to report her missing at .am on May , the inquest has heard. Detective Constable Tina Gilfoyle, of Nottinghamshire Police, said the mum and Ambers stepfather, Danny Peat, had been to Tesco and had tea while the youngster was missing.   Providing background of the the teenagers disappearance, Ms Gilfoyle said the family had moved  times in Ambers letime. The hearing has been told there was no evidence of physical neglect and no sign Amber was malnourished at the time of her death. Home Office pathologist Frances Hollingbury said there were no traces of alcohol or drugs in her body and no suggestion of a mental illness. A post-mortem found no evidence to suggest anyone  was involved. The inquest continues. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or byemailingjo@samaritans.org

story: NewsWoman reveals what your name TASTES like - and its bad news for Meghan MarkleJulie McDowall, from Glasgow, says Jesus is a Malteser, Georgia tastes like a big fat ball of wool and Grace is a soft turnip in a pot of vegetable soupShareCommentsByErin Black:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsJulie McDowall has an unusual condition which means her sensory systems are more intwined than normal "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who can taste peoples names is causing widespread hilarity. Jesus is a Malteser, Georgia tastes like a big fat ball of wool and Grace is a soft turnip in a pot of vegetable soup. And while Millicent is a bowl of lightly-browned mince, Lucy tastes like a bag of strawberry laces and Ross resembles a Greggs sausage roll. Julie McDowall has an unusual condition called synesthesia which means her sensory systems are more entwined than normal. Part of the affliction means the inidual can join objects such as letters, shapes, numbers or peoples names with a sensory perception like smell, colour or flavour. On Sunday evening, the Glasgow journalist posted: I have synethesia which means I can taste words. Ask me what your name tastes like. Scroll down for more examples...  The tweet subsequently went viral with thousands of Twitter users asking what she associated with their name, Plymouth Live reports. Ms McDowall later tweeted she had received an excess of six million notications over a -hour period and would not be able to sort through the backlog of monikers. In order to screen the requests, she introduced a Paypal filter. Users were invited to donate to her weekly nuclear war podcast, The Atomic Hobo, in exchange for the sampling of three names. The donation amount is unspecied and presumably can be as large or a small as you like. Erin is a cola-flavoured boiled sweet which has been dusted in cocoa powder, reads one tweet. She continues to state that Hannah tastes like an off banana, Amy is a packet of raw bacon strips and Shane tastes like furniture polish.  Adrian is an Aero bar, Charlotte a raspberry lolly and Leah is thick, gloopy custard. Rebecca is shortbread and Jamie is rain on a window pain. And Meghan Markle is particularly off the wall, tasting like plain broken Hula Hoops and an itchy scab respectively. Kate Middleton, on the other hand, is a hearty slice of cake. Donald is a rubber duck, sliced in two and dipped in vinegar. Louise is soft toffee and Benjamin is a combination of ginger and the clear plastic handle of a screwdriver. Paul tastes like the fondant inside a Creme Egg and Scott is a Rich Tea biscuit. William and Julie are both watering eyeballs.  Rob and Robert are both heads. Rob is a robbers head. He is wearing a balaclava andyou bite his head you see it is made full of chocolate. Robert is a gnomes head and biting it shows it is full of strawberry fondant. Unfortunately for Duncan, he is a burp. And Joe is a leathery, chunky button on an old mans cardigan. The scientic name for Ms McDowalls condition is lexical-gustatory synesthesia, a form only .% of the population has. The perceptual phenomena has been traced back as far as the th century where it is reported a blind man experienced the colour scarlet when he heard the sound of a trumpet. It does not just have to be flavours though, some names conjure up feelings or images for Ms McDowall. For example, Ingrid is beads on an abacus and Eleanor is grey tissue paper being ripped. title: idlewilds andrew wasylyk to launch solo album with show at home city of dundee
story: A Dundee musician who plays with Scots’ indie rockers Idlewild is set to launch his new solo album with a city show this week.Andrew Wasylyk will bring his eight-piece band to the Gardyne Theatre on Thursday at .pm to launch his third record, an ambient album called The Paralian.The Dundee-born-and-bred songwriter said he “can’t wait” to play in the Ferry theatre.“I’m bringing musicians from Dundee and further afield – I’m excited to play on stage with some really great musicians,” he said.The title of Andrew’s new record means “dweller by the sea” and the recording has been inspired by the “incredibly beautul” Angus coast.It is the culmination of a residency at Hospitalfield in Arbroath, where he wrote music for a rare th Century Erard Grecian harp.Andrew made trips to the Bell Rock lighthouse and Seaton clfs to record audio and find inspiration and has used all manner of instruments to capture the “sound” of the coast.He followed a similar process for his last album, the Dundee-inspired Themes For Buildings and Spaces, with songs such as Lower Dens Works, Menzieshill and The Howff.Andrew added: “I hadn’t really considered how the coast has affected my le but I don’t think I could ever live in a land-locked city.“It’s quite comforting having the sea and the horizon always there.”For Andrew, who plays bass in Idlewild under his birth name of Andrew Mitchell, playing at the Gardyne is important, as he remains in Dundee to this day.The show comes just a few months after the “honour” of playing to thousands in Slessor Gardens at the D Festival, heralding the opening of the VA.He said: “A lot of the music I played there was written for that kind of area of Dundee, so it was nice to play it there – and to play with Gary Clark later in the day, as he’s a pal.“I think it’s exciting, what’s happening to Dundee at the moment.“We all now feel the sort of sht that’s happening in the city, the sense of change, and there’s an influx of tourism which is great.“I just hope it helps the people who need help the most.“There are still a lot of people north of the Kingsway who aren’t aware of the VA – and they have no reason to, because it doesn’t affect their lives.“Hopefully this sht will help make sure nobody is left behind.”

title: ivan golac returning to dundee united for hall of fame induction
story: Dundee United’s original Scottish Cup legend Ivan Golac will be back at Tannadice next month when he’s to be inducted in the club’s Hall of Fame.The man with the magic hat famously led the Tangerines to their first-ever Scottish Cup success when he led them to a shock victory over Rangers at Hampden in .Ending United’s Hampden hoodoo that had seen them lose their previous six finals and his flamboyant managerial style made Golac an instant hero.And now the club are recognising his contribution to their history by adding him to their Hall of Fame.His name will join the likes of Doug Smith, Dave Narey, Paul Hegarty and Jim McLean on the roll of honour.Also being inducted this year is former player Tommy Neilson, along with two others whose names are still to be revealed.The Hall of Fame Dinner takes place in the West End Lounge at Tannadice on February .

title: jesse curran to miss dundees scottish cup replay at queen of the south
story: Midfielder Jesse Curran will miss Dundee’s Scottish Cup replay at Queen of the South today because of the hamstring injury he suffered in Saturday’s defeat against Motherwell.The Dark Blues are assessing the problem that saw Curran pull up with just five minutes on the clock at Dens Park.However, the fear is the Australian, who was limping heavily as he headed for the dressing-room after watching the first half from the bench, could be sidelined for several weeks.That would be a major blow for both boss Jim McIntyre and the -year-old who has made  appearances in an excellent first campaign as a top-team regular.Curran’s form has seen him monitored by his home country’s national team while Philippines manager Sven-Goran Eriksson has offered him the chance to be part of their set-up.He qualies for them through his mother and is also eligible for Scotland, where his father was born.“The physio is assessing Jesse and we’ll just have to see how he is,” said his club boss.Jim was left frustrated by the single-goal defeat against ’Well that came courtesy of a second-half penalty from David Turnbull, following a rash Ryan Inniss tackle on Elliot Frear.The gaffer, though, took consolation from the way his side dominated most of the play.“To say it was frustrating is stating the obvious because we put so much into the game. We didn’t deserve to lose that game, in my opinion we deserved to win it,” he said.“But we didn’t punish Motherwell in the first half when we were on top and paid the price for a bad decision in our own penalty box.“The big manis honest enough to put his hands up because there was no need to go to ground. With the chances we had there were also mistakes at the other end of the pitch.“There were plenty positives to take from the way we played.“It’s just about getting that decision-making a bit better.“Overall, I was pleased with the performance evenwe didn’t get the result we deserved.“In our position we need points so you have to make better decisions and convert the pressure into points. But that’s the way I want my teams to play.”

title: kids charity targeted by vandals gets donation by dundee council during opening ceremony
story: A children’s charity targeted by vandals was handed a surprise donation by Dundee City Council during its grand opening ceremony.Spectrum, based at Mains Halls on Claverhouse Road, was presented with a £ cheque by Lord Provost Ian Borthwick.The donation came after the Tele reported on the “mindless” damage wreaked by vandals over the festive break.Staff at the autism youth charity ed from the holidays to find £ of toys and equipment fire-damaged beyond repair.Mr Borthwick said: “The work Spectrum do here is invaluable for the children and for their families, and as a council we have to show support to services that need it.“I am most impressed with what I’ve been shown today.”The grand opening was a cause for celebration, as it officially marked Mains Halls becoming Spectrum’s permanent home.The group has been based at the halls for  years, but its future had been cast into doubt when the Church of Scotland put the halls up for sale.The charity bought the halls outright thanks to a donation from the late Margaret Craig, from Glasgow.Margaret and her husband John have a grandson who had attended Spectrum – so when Margaret left a “substantial” sum in her will to support autism charities, John couldn’t think of a more deserving beneficiary.John was present to unveil a plaque commemorating the grand opening and Margaret’s donation.The halls will also be renamed Craig Halls in their honour.John said: “It’s very good to be here today. After my we died I wanted to do something special with the money she had left, something really suitable.“We had a grandson that attended here about  years ago so it was a very worthwhile cause.“It has been very warming to see the number of businesses and people who have contributed to help in any way they can.”

title: tom duthie dundee united need to start performing in the big games
story: Despite the major disappointment of the defeat at Ayr United, the consolation for Dundee United fans at the moment has to be the fact they have become genuine promotion contenders under Robbie Neilson.The gap to the top of the table has stretched to six points again because of that Friday night loss at Somerset Park coupled with Ross County’s victory over Alloa on Saturday afternoon.It can’t be forgotten United’s poor goal dference effectively means right now the gap to the top is seven points.With just  games to go, time is also running out for United to make up the lost ground and clinch promotion at the first time of asking.Boosted by the January signings that are set to continue in the final few days of the window,they can gel quickly enough, Neilson will believe the deficit can by clawed back and, in a Championship race that’s seen every team drop points regularly, even a decent winning run could do that.The manager’s overall record since he arrived in October does also give some reason for Arabs not to give up hope just yet.Since his debut win at Partick Thistle in mid-October, with , his team are the leading points gatherers in the second tier.By beating Alloa in Dingwall on Saturday, County took their points tally over the same period to  and while no one would argue the fact promoted Ayr are having an excellent first campaign back at this level, they have been showing signs of running out of steam.Between their hugely impressive - win at Tannadice right at the end of November and their repeat success over United the other night, Ian McCall’s team had gone five league games without a win and also, of course, suffered that humiliating Scottish Cup exit at the hands of juniors Auchinleck Talbot.If that, and the points tally under the new manager, provides encouragement, what continues to be a major concern for United is their poor record against the others at the top end of the table.Friday was their fth clash with the top two on league business and, to date, the record reads played five, lost four, won one, score two and conceded .Add to that a League Cup loss up at County in July and what you have is a worrying statistic.Without wishing to paint an even darker picture, they have also only drawn two clashes with Inverness with both coming when the Highlanders were sitting in one of the promotion play-off places.If they are to realise American owner Mark Ogren’s dream of going up automatically during his first months in charge, it’s a statement of the obvious to say the big-game record has to improve drastically.Should it, United can still get to where they want to be. They’ve two games to come against County and one final crack at Ayr and, of those showdowns, two are at Tannadice.Yes, the two heaviest defeats of the season came there against County and Ayr but under Neilson that second defeat was the only one he’s suffered in seven home games so far.And last time he sent out a team to face County he did mastermind what was without doubt the best win of the campaign to date, a gritty - success on their patch, in November.If the manager can mould his rebuilt team over the next few weeks, wins like that one can be repeated.They’ll have to be, or United’s big-game failures will see them negotiating even more vital outings in the play-offs.

title: Call for Inverness to get a share of cash for shop conversions
story: CONCERNS have been raised that Inverness could be denied a share of funding to help the hardest-pressed local high streets turn empty shops into housing.Mike Smith, manager of the cityrsquos Business Improvement Districtfears a move by the Federation of Small Businessesto persuade the Scottish Government to split a pound million fund between the poorest-performing high streets only could see a relatively buoyant Inverness miss out.ldquoI donrsquot think thatrsquos fair, he said.ldquoAll high streets are under certain pressures. Retail is a commercial venture and we do not think that public funds should be given tosupport one retail sector against another.ldquoI think this pound million should be fairly split on a population basis and should be used in an equal way to improve the infrastructure.Mr Smith stressed that some local authorities will already be investing in this way and their successes ldquoshould not be held against them.He said the redevelopment of Academy Streetrsquos former Farmfoods supermarket was ldquoa good example of shops being turned into homes in the city with the local authorityrsquos support.The development there will include  one-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats as well as four retail and office units on the ground floor.A spokesman for FSB nationally said: ldquoIt is far too early to tell which high streets will benefit from this fund.ldquoWersquore making the case for each local authority to use this money in the places that it could make the most dference.FSB Highlands and Islands development manager David Richardson said: ldquoRather than spreading the money too thinly for it to have any impact, the FSB wants it to be focused on ersying our hardest-pressed high streets and is calling for local authorities to establish new co-investment funds to improve and convert existing properties. We must make more of what wersquove already got. Allied to this is the need for joined-up thinking amongst public bodies. Given that thriving high streets and village centres are inextricably linked to the health and wellbeing of their communities, it is important that all interested parties work in partnership.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she would be calling on colleagues to get round the table for some strategic planning to make sure the city gets a share of the funding.She believes the rate of shop closures in the Highland capital and the long waiting list for homes puts the city at the front of the queue.She said: ldquoIrsquom going to have a chat with the city centre manager, David Hass, and get people around the table to see how we can get our hands on that money.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

But it is our intention to grow that business to about  jobs in the next few years.ldquoThe building at Daviot would also have an office for Brightcare. Itrsquos a well known building, bigger than we need for an office and there is space for both operations.ldquoI have already had expressions of interest from restaurant operators and a dog grooming business which would fit in well to because it is a popular area for people walking their dogs.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tuck, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

story: The Courtyard by Marriot will be situated within Inverness Airport Business Park and it set to open its doors later this year.Owned and developed by Molo Hotels, the property will be operated by the independent hotel management company RBH.Chief business development officer at RBH, Andrew Robb, said the company is delighted to be working alongside Molo hotels and Polcom Construction for the project.ldquoWersquove forged a strong working relationship with Molo Hotels and Polocom Construction over the years and are thrilled to be working with them on what promises to be another outstanding property, said Mr Robb.The -bedroom hotel plans include meeting and fitness facilities as well as a bar and bistro.Contractor Polocom Construction has started the production of bedrooms in Poland before they are transported to the site near Inverness airport in May.A spokesman for RBH has said that the hotel is set to be open by the end of the year: ldquoWhile we canrsquot give an exact opening date at the moment, the hotel is scheduled to open in quarter  of  she said.Molo Hotels changed their name from Polocom Developments in .Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Leading Inverness football figure to live on with launch of fundraising campaign
story: THE memory of a leading Inverness football figure will live on with the launch of a fundraising campaign to help renal patients and raise awareness of kidney failure.Sandyrsquos Army will be launched in memory of Sandy Corcoran, the founder of Inverness City Ladies, on what would have been his th birthday.Mr Corcoran, who died three days before Christmas, had lived with type one diabetes for many years and then developed kidney failure resulting in him undergoing long dialysis sessions in Raigmore Hospitalrsquos renal unit.His family, including we, Valerie, son Steven and daughter Ashley Mackinnon, plus five grandchildren, are now raising funds for the unit at a dinner dance featuring live music and comedians at the cityrsquos Kingsmillrsquos Hotel on April .At the stroke of midnight, Sandyrsquos Army will be launched heralding more fundraising events in the coming year.Mrs Mackinnon said just  tickets remain for the event after  were snapped up in three days.ldquoWe want the night to be a massive celebration and we want to remember what an unbelievable person he was, she said. ldquoIt is going to be a sensational tribute to him as a person helping others and he would have wanted it no other way. It will be a hard day but I feel that being with those who loved him it will make it easier.Although Mr Corcoran was diagnosed with diabetes  years ago, he managed his condition but then developed kidney failure five years ago.With the support of his family, he started home dialysis but when it became too dficult he had to swap to six-hour sessions three days a week in the renal unit.ldquoThe unit became like a family to us, Mrs Mackinnon recalled. ldquoThey were just incredible to my dad. I noticed he was never on his own. They work tirelessly  hours a day, seven days a week.He was due to have a kidney and pancreas transplant but then developed bone marrow failure resulting in him having blood transfusions which meant he could not have a transplant.Sadly, Mr Corcoran, who was also the manager of Inverness Precast, died on December . Over  people attended his funeral.ldquoHe faced everything with the most unbelievable courage. I never once heard dad complain, Mrs Mackinnon said.She added that the family want to give something back to the renal unit and, as well as the dinner, planned fundraisers include an ascent of Ben Nevis.ldquoThis is a way of helping others through his memory.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: New Lochardil hotel owner pledges to make investment
story: NEW owners of a well established Inverness hotel have promised more investment to make it even more attractive to visitors.Lochardil House Hotel has become the second mainland hotel bought by Skye-based Perle Hotels and the group has been advertising for staff to get ready for the summer.The Victorian mansion, which was built in  as the home of Inverness MP Charles Fraser-Mackintosh, has been a hotel since .It was previously owned by Eileen Fraser, who bought the hotel in . More recently she has expanded the hotel with the addition of a purpose-built banqueting suite, a conservatory restaurant, new kitchens and a separate  bedroom garden wing, more than doubling its accommodation provision.Perle Hotels marketing manager Nina Ghita said the group wanted to build on the hotelrsquos heritage and had no plans to change its name.ldquoWe want to keep those unique quirks and the history. Those are really important, but there are always things that can be improved, she said.ldquoWe focus on the Highlands and Islands and we invest quite heavily into the hotels, provide more jobs and just try and make something special within the area. The same thing will be happening with Lochardil. Obviously the hotel is in a really good position as it is. We donrsquot have any concrete plans as yet, but there will be heavy investment down the road.Unlike the grouprsquos previous hotels, which required major renovations, she does not anticipate anything so drastic. There are no immediate plans to add other north hotels to the group, but Ms Ghita pointed out there were opportunities available all the time.ldquoWe are a growing company, she said. ldquoThere will be future expansion plans but nothing concrete at the moment.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Noel Gallaghers High Flying Birds to play Inverness concert
story: They will perform at Bught Park on Saturday, June , as part of lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo, a series of summer music concerts planned for the city.Last year was a successful period for the former Oasis star, who landed a Mercury Prize nomination for the High Flying Birdsrsquo album Who Built The Moon , the bandrsquos third number one in a row. They also toured extensively across North America, Europe and Asia with Noel picking up the Best Album and Solo Artist accolades at the Q Awards.Joining the line-up for the evening, are two big names from the music scene. Indie rock band, Razorlight and Neon Waltz shy- from John OrsquoGroats - will be special guests on June .Local concert promoter, LCC Live is organising this concert, as part of its lsquoLive in the Cityrsquo. Carlie Davidson of LCC Live, said: ldquoNoel is a legend of the music industry, who along with his band, will take to the stage and deliver an array of classic songs from his career including recent hits Holy Mountain and Itrsquos A Beautul World.ldquoWersquore absolutely delighted to be organising his only Scottish outdoor show in  at our fantastic arena in Bught Park. It will be a great night and Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds, is a superb addition to our eclectic series of live concerts this summer.Tickets for Noel Gallagherrsquos High Flying Birds concert in Inverness go on sale at am on Friday from Ticketline www.ticketline    or in person from Cafferys Menswear, Eastgate Shopping Centre, Inverness, IV PP.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Parents criticise new school bus service across Inverness
story: SCHOOL bus services have been in chaos since a council contract changed hands at the start of the month it has been claimed.Parents say a move to double up dedicated school runs with services for the general public since transport giant Stagecoach took over the Highland Council schools contract from DE Coaches on January  has seen pupils regularly forced to endure late-running and dangerously overcrowded buses.Police have also confirmed they are investigating allegations that pupils were threatened with a weapon on board a bus between Kirkhill and Charleston Academy on January .Mum Carol Paterson, whose daughter travels from Croy to Culloden Academy, said the problems are known about across Inverness.ldquoThe children at Croy are waiting sometimes up to  minutes in freezing conditions because the buses are now regularly late, she said.ldquoAnd when they board the bus there are not enough seats.Jools Lawson, whose daughter attends Charleston Academy, said: ldquoKids are regularly having to stand on a jam-packed bus or being put off altogether and told to wait for another one.ldquoThe service is disgusting and Stagecoach brush our complaints under the carpet.Posts from a private Facebook group set up for parents of pupils using school buses and shown to the Inverness Courier make clear the extent of unhappiness since the changeover.Other alleged incidents include children being put off a bus beside a busy main road without a pavement and two incidents involving Inverness Royal Academy pupils ndash one where a bus did not turn up at home time and another where the bus was too small to accommodate them.Highland Council has issued two separate statements in response to concerns raised ndash one with regard to a public service operating en route to Inverness Gaelic Primary stating it is unlikely to involve ldquoroutes which the public are likely to want to use and another on the Charleston Academy-Kirkhill route stating ldquomeasures have been put in place to make improvements.Despite this an online petition has been launched calling for the reinstatement of dedicated school services.Signed by almost  people so far it states: ldquoWhen putting our children on a school bus it used to be the case that it was only school children on these buses, therefore anyone travelling was accounted for and any incidents easily dealt with and tracked.ldquoNow we have opened the floodgates to allowing our children to be exposed to anything on these buses.Councillor for Culloden and Ardersier, Glynis Campbell-Sinclair, said Highland Council needs to launch its own investigation into whether there is a serious problem with how buses taking pupils to and from schools operate.ldquoThey cannot jam pack children onto buses like pilchards and hope there is not going to be an accident - especially in this weather, she said.ldquoEvery parent that sends their child to school by bus is depending on the council to ensure that happens safely.ldquoIt is the councilrsquos responsibility as corporate parent to ensure these children get to school safely.A spokeswoman for Stagecoach North Scotland said: ldquoSince we started operating the additional school contracts on January  there have been some issues with capacity we have identied and are working to resolve.ldquoWe are working closely with Highland Council to resolve these problems by issuing school children with passes allocating them to specic buses to prevent the overloading problems we have seen.She added that in terms of the issues raised by Mrs Paterson an additional bus is now running to and from Croy.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: Work starts on new outlets at Eastgate Shopping Centre
story: WORK has begun at the Eastgate Shopping Centre in Inverness to develop four food outlets.The units, suitable for restaurant or bar operators, are being created by the reconfiguration of two existing shops fronting Falcon Square.Burger King UK is the first operator to sign up while talks are ongoing with operators for the other units.In addition, a new kiosk will be created fronting the Falcon Square mall entrance. Possible uses include an outlet for a food takeaway.The development comes as the cityrsquos nearby rail station is set to undergo a pound million upgrade while a public consultation is currently ongoing into a bold vision to transform Academy Street to make it more pedestrian-friendly.Alasdair Murdoch, chief executive of Burger King UK, said: ldquoWe are excited to expand the Burger King brand in Inverness and look forward to welcoming guests to experience the great-tasting, high-quality food that has delighted Burger King customers for  years.Local building and construction company Compass expects to hand over the units in late May to be fitted out and managing director Thom Macleod is delighted it has been appointed principal contractor for the redevelopment of the former Monsoon and Mamas and Papas unit.ldquoHaving been involved extensively in the planning of the project, it is pleasing to now be making preparations for the works to get formally under way on site, he said.Previous proposals involved an extension into Falcon Square or rooftop bar but were altered to attract a wider range of operators.Centre manager Jackie Cuddy said it will be business usual while work proceeds.ldquoWe are delighted to see the works progressing after several enforced delays over the yearsshe said. ldquoThe market may have changed since we first started out on this journey but we are still optimistic that we can provide a great addition to the night time economy of Inverness with this development.Wednesday  Jan  : PM

title: mcinnes wants to add a wee bit more to squad
story: Dons boss Derek McInnes today confirmed he hopes to bring in one more signing before the transfer window closes.The winter window shuts tomorrow and McInnes will step up his attempts to strengthen his squad.Aberdeen have been linked with the potential loanof former Dons winger Jonny Hayes from Celtic.However, it is understood finances would rule out any chance of the Reds taking Hayes back to Pittodrie.Aberdeen moved into the fth round of the Scottish Cup last night with a - replay defeat of Stenhousemuir at Ochilview.They will now face Championship Queen of the South in the last .McInnes said: “I would still like to maybe bring one more inwe could.“On the day of the cup tie I just took a step back from it as I was just trying to concentrate on the game.“The game required our full focus.“We will see where we are and will make a few calls after the game.“However, we are getting bodies back as Devlin is not too far away and Mark Reynolds is back.“Defensively we are not too bad and we have some good attacking options and some youngsters coming through.“If we don’t manage to bring anyone in it will not be the end of the world.“But just for the challenges ahead I would like to add a wee bit more to the squadwe can.”Aberdeen also enquired about the possibility of bringing Celtic’s Scotland international winger Lewis Morgan in on loan until the end of the season.However, Sunderland boss Jack Ross, who worked with Morgan at St Mirren, looks set to secure him.McInnes said there have been a number of players the Dons have enquired about in this window.He said: “There have been a few players we have asked the question about and spoke to ious managers about.“Some conversations have been more positive than others.“But just because you ask the questionthere is anything definite in it.”Meanwhile, McInnes confirmed Scotland international centre-back Scott McKenna is set to miss the next two to three games with a hamstring injury.McKenna was sent for a scan on Monday to assess the injury that forced him off in the - draw with Kilmarnock.McInnes said: “As expected it was not as bad as the last time – when Scott got injured against Rangers, when he was out for six, seven weeks.“Scott will miss the next two or three games, but will hopefully be back for the cup tie.“The good news is it was nothing signicant and was just like a grade one tear.“He will hopefully be back before too long.”Aberdeen eased into the next round with goals from Niall McGinn, Sam Cosgrove, Greg Stewart and an own goal.It was Stewart’s first goal since ing to Pittodrie on a loan deal from Birmingham until the end of the season.Stewart spent last season on loan at Pittodrie, but spent the first half of this campaign at Kilmarnock.McInnes said: “It was a brilliant finish as he just got enough pace on the dink to get it over the line.”Aberdeen had been held - at Pittodrie in the initial tie having led -.In the aftermath of that draw McInnes admitted his side took their foot off the gas.This time the Reds were ruthless and there was never any chance of a repeat of Stenhousemuir’s famous - Scottish Cup defeat of the Dons in .McInnes said: “Our approach in the first game was absolutely spot on and we got the first goal.“We were just wasteful with chances and were maybe a bit rusty.“We were punished.“In the replay it was all about having that focus, calmness and using our experience.“We have been a good cup team over the last few years and I get reminded of the time Aberdeen lost at Stenhousemuir to Terry Christie’s team often enough.“It is easy to see why people maybe look at this as trickier.“But the players approached it right and we were clinical in the first half.“We spoke at half-time about making sure there was no sloppiness, so I was disappointed that we lost the goal.“To score from inside our six-yard box isn’t good enough and we need to make sure that was better.“But by and large there were some good performances and we stretched them and worked them.“We looked like a proper team and I am delighted we managed to score four goals and threatened to score more.”

title: 119000 children in need cash boost for charlie house
story: An Aberdeen charity has been given a whopping £, in order to help children and babies with complex disabilities.Charlie House was awarded the six-figure sum, which will be paid out over three years, from the BBC’s Children In Need fund.Bosses at the charity said the incredible sum will “change the lives” of children across the north-east.Charlie House was founded in  and currently runs a number of services for youngsters with complex disabilities and or le-limiting conditions and their families.These include activity and siblings clubs, one-to-one support, annual adventure trips and a community nurse who works in hospitals.The funding will be used to provide therapeutic, supportive and fun activities for young people in order to allow siblings to better come to terms with their brother or sister’s le-limiting condition.It’s hoped that in turn will allow them to better manage their emotions, develop new friendships and experience a more positive home environment.Tracy Johnstone, chairwoman and founder of Charlie House, said: “We could not expand our reach to families and young people in the north-east of Scotland without the support of BBC Children In Need. This grant will go on to change the lives of so many young people and give them the support they need, when they need it.“This project support will improve the mental and emotional wellbeing of siblings of children with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions by providing one-to-one and group or family therapeutic support, sibling support and pre-and post-bereavement support.”In November Charlie House announced its plans to build a specialist support centre based in four acres of ground at Woodend Hospital.Aimed at providing respite for families, it will also feature a number of dferent facilities, and will be the first of its kind in the north-east.At present, people have to travel more than  miles to the nearest respite centre, which is in Kinross.In the north-east alone, there are more than , babies, children and young people with complex disabilities.The Big Build Appeal aims to raise £ million, which will allow the construction and maintenance of the building.It will comprise eight children’s bedrooms with accompanying family accommodation, and will also have flexible office and meeting space for employees.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children In Need, said: “We are committed to improving the lives of those children and young people who need it most.“Our support to Charlie House will enable them to make real and lasting changes to children with le-limiting conditions and their families across the north-east of Scotland. To quote Charlie House, le is precious, we believe that it should also be full of fun and friendship and look forward to seeing this funding in action.”BBC Children In Need has raised more than £ billion for children and young people across the UK.It supports more than , projects for those facing a range of disadvantages, including living in poverty, being disabled or ill, or experiencing distress, neglect or trauma. To help with the fundraising, donate online by visiting bit.ly ROBktF or call the Charlie House office on  .To find out more about how to support the Big Build Appeal contact the charity at bigbuild@charliehouse.org.uk

title: aberdeen burns supper event raises thousands for charities
story: Two charities are set to receive four-figure sums after an Aberdeen Burns Supper.The event, which was held last Friday and was organised by Granite PR, raised more than £, for Flying Start, the partnership between British Airways and Comic Relief, and Inspire, an organisation for adults with learning disabilities and additional support needs in the north-east.Organiser Brett Jackson, of Granite PR, said: “One of our main aims this year was to increase our focus on raising money for good causes and I am delighted we have achieved such a great total.“I am very grateful to everyone who supported our efforts in so many ways and helped us to get our  calendar of events off to an excellent start.”Video: North-east Scouts celebrate Burns Night with traditional Address to a Haggis" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local video-north-east-scouts-celebrate-burns-night-with-traditional-address-to-a-haggis embed # secretXUtATekTi" data-secret"XUtATekTi" width"" "" title"#Video: North-east Scouts celebrate Burns Night with traditional Address to a Haggis# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: aberdeen uni offers apprenticeships to orkney residents
story: An Aberdeen university is set to offer apprenticeships to remote students.People studying with Robert Gordon Universityin Orkney will now be able to work locally as part of a graduate apprenticeship, as well as gaining their degree.Named the Orkney Project, the university believes that the initiative will help to develop solutions to the challenges of island le.The university is supporting  placements for its students in construction, business engineering and IT courses.Cath Russell, who is carrying out a graduate apprenticeship at the European Marine Energy Centre, said: “I’m really enjoying learning the theory behind what I do in practice.“I’m finding applying the theory to my own company is really helpful, it makes it more realI can see it in action.“I learn better by doing so being able to practically use my learning in my day to day job is great.”

title: plans lodged to create 500 600 home coastal community in aberdeen
story: Plans have been lodged to create a new “coastal community” in Aberdeen – including building  to  new homes.Cognito Oak LLP has applied to Aberdeen City Council to build the new residential development at Cloverhill, Bridge of Don, on land to the east of the A Ellon Road.A new recycling centre, shops, eateries and community facilities have also been proposed for the site, near Bridge of Don Industrial Estate. vw, px"  In a letter, Halliday Fraser Munro, planning consultants for the application, said: “The proposed residential elements would comprise a mix of market and mixed-tenure affordable homes to meet local and market needs.“A range of other uses would also be provided, including the provision of local shops and servicesto create a sustainable mixed-use coastal community within the city.“Other uses will support local employment generation and provide facilities that support the community.”The application is the latest in a series of new housing developments for the area.The Grandhome Trust has planning permission in principle for a community of , homes, including commercial, shopping, leisure and public space.With long-term potential for , homes, the community is being planned and developed by the trust, a family-led entity that has held the land for more than  years.The public will get the chance to view the proposals for Cloverhill at a consultation event planned for Tuesday February  at St Columba’s Church in Bridge of Don.The drop-in exhibition will be manned by members of the design team who will deal with any queries.There will be a number of display  that provide background to the site, illustrate the proposals and explain the planning process.

title: possible traffic delays as aberdeens ultrafast broadband rollout continues
story: A number of Aberdeen roads are set to be closed to install ultrafast internet.The Cityfibre scheme is hoped to make Aberdeen the first city in Scotland to have web speeds of up to one gigabyte per second.As part of the scheme,  miles of cables have had to be placed under city streets.Some of the disruption caused by this work is now set to hit the Rosehill area of the city.Starting on February , roads in that area will face a series of partial closures.Morgan Road, Cairncry Avenue, Cairncry Terrace, Ash-hill Road, Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Drive are all facing partial closure until March .A subsequent batch of roads have also been earmarked for work.Ash-hill Place and Cornhill Drive are next on the list, with closures due toto Cairncry Terrace and Ash-hill Road before work ends on March .Along with the partial closures of the roads, a ban on parking will also be imposed on the affected streets between am on February  and pm on March .Aberdeen City Council has warned that any cars parked illegally will be removed and must be recovered at the expense of the owner.Meanwhile, Cityfibre is also set to shut down a street in the heart of the city centre.Exchange Street, between its junction with Trinity Lane and Guild Street, will be closed for the work between am on February  and February  at pm.The one-way restriction on Exchange Street will also be suspended during that period between the junction with Guild Street and Imperial Lane.

title: ayr blind swimmer takes water
story: NewsAyr blind swimmer takes to water to raise cash for charityAyr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN NewsFern is splitting her charity swim between Prestwick and Troon pools "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA blind swimmer has taken to the water in a bid to raise charity cash. Ayr girl Fern Walker, will attempt more than  s over the coming weeks. The -year-old is putting in the aqua miles at her favourite pools in Prestwick and Troon in the hope of raising more than pound. Fern, who lives with Bardet-Biedl Syndrome , is completing the challenge with the aid of her care team at Partners For Inclusion. She said: “I really enjoy my swimming and I come to the pool three times a week. “It will be tough to complete all these s and I’ve just started out – but I’m enjoying it so far.” BBS is a rare genetic disorder with symptoms including sight loss, obesity and reduced kidney . Like many other sufferers, Fern was also born with extra digits. The condition affects just one in , people across the world.   Sister Leigh, , said: “We’re all incredible proud of Fern and what she’s trying to achieve. “She was diagnosed with BBS at a very young age and her condition, particularly her sight, has deteriorated through time. “But she is never one to complain so this is typical of her attitude – she’s just determined to get out there and do something worthwhile.” Staff at Prestwick and Troon pools are helping encourage Fern during her bid, as she tackles up to  s at a time during each session. And the former Mainholm Academy pupil hopes to complete the marathon water trip while stacking up the cash for BBS UK. The charity provides support for those living with the condition and their carers. Leigh added: “It would be niceFern’s story going public could help with her fundraising effort. “She has her small group of friends and carers but it would mean the world to her to get support from further afield and raise as much as she can.” •To donate visit https:www.justgiving fundraising fern-walker

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: caravan caught alight sparks major
story: NewsCaravan which caught alight sparks major fire operationThe derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN NewsThe fire spread to the adjacent property "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA caravan which caught alight sparked a large scale fire operation as it set ablaze to a neighbouring house. The derelict property on Kilmarnock Road in Monkton went up in flames last Thursday night as the caravan attached to it caught fire. Four fire engines raced to the scene to tackle the blaze. And an aerial appliance was also mobilised by Scottish Fire and Rescue service. Firefighters battled the flames well into the night . The road remained closed after pm, eyewitnesses said. And a fire engine stayed at the scene the following morning.   One eyewitness said: “The house was right up in smoke. It was a big fire and luckily they got it when they did or it could have been worse.” A Scottish Fire and Rescue spokesman said: “We were alerted at .pm on Thursday, January  to a fire involving a caravan attached to a derelict property in Monkton. “Operations Control mobilised four fire engines and an aerial appliance to the scene, on Kilmarnock Road, where crews extinguished the fire, which had partly spread to the adjacent property building. “There were no casualties. “A single fire engine remains at the scene this morningto ensure the area remains safe.”
